metadata.title: Afghanistan: Minutes of FSAC Monthly Meeting (17 January 2024) [Meeting Minutes]
metadata.content:
title: Afghanistan: Minutes of FSAC Monthly Meeting (17 January 2024) [Meeting Minutes] 
 content: The members of EWIMWG delivered a comprehensive presentation on early warning information to the cluster partners. Below, you'll find the key highlights from the pivotal presentation.
- Precipitation: According to all models, For January 2023- Marh 2024, there are most likely chance of above average precipitation in most of Afghanistan. However, rainfall analysis for the period since 1 November shows below-average precipitation over the country (10-100mm anomalies, locally higher in the West. o Snow: Negative snow depth, and snow water equivalent anomalies are greatest in the Northeast as well as along the northern slopes of the central mountains. As a result, abnormal dryness is placed in northern, eastern, and northeastern Afghanistan.
- Temperature: During the outlook period, 7-day mean maximum temperatures are forecasted to be well above average across Afghanistan. During Jan-Mar 2024, various climate models have consistently forecasted above-average e temperatures during this outlook period.
- Price: WFP in-kind food basket in Afghani has shown a continuous decline since reaching its peak in June 2022 up to September 2023, but had a slight increase in October 2023, followed by a decrease in December 2023. The Food Security and Agriculture Cluster (FSAC) food basket used for cash-based transfers (CBTs).
The national average AFN price of FSAC basket in the month of December 2023 was 2.6 percent lower than the last month and higher by 24 percent compared to the pre– Covid period (second week of March 2020). The national average USD price decreased negligibly by 1.5 percent in the month of December 2023 compared to the previous month, 5 percent lower than the price one year ago and 13 percent higher compared to month of June 2021 (before the recent conflicts and political change).

claims.sentence: [meeting minutes] members ewimwg delivered comprehensive presentation early warning information cluster partners.

metadata.title: Afghanistan: Minutes of FSAC Monthly Meeting (24 April 2024) [Meeting Minutes]
metadata.content:
title: Afghanistan: Minutes of FSAC Monthly Meeting (24 April 2024) [Meeting Minutes] 
 content: The Early Warning Information Working Group (EWIWG) presented a comprehensive overview of early warning information to the cluster partners. Here are the key highlights from the presentation.
➢ Precipitation: rainfall for the 2023/24 winter wet season, from October 2023 to March 2024, is most likely to be below average, with areas with average values. Average precipitation is most likely to occur from March to May 2024, during the wet spring season. Spring rains are expected to have normal timing and distribution, with minimal adverse impact on typical agricultural activities through flooding.
➢ Temperature: Above average daily mean temperatures are most likely through September 2024. Extreme temperatures during May-July and July-September (upper quintile) are 2-3 times more likely than climatology. The consequences of the above-average temperature may be moisture stress in rainfed crops and rangelands and reduced water availability, mainly in the downstream areas that may experience extended dry spells.
➢ Snow Water Volumes: Given below-average antecedent precipitation and current snow water volumes, below-average snow water volumes are expected in the coming months. However, there is more snow than in 2023, given recent accumulations due to above-average precipitation in February and March. Above-average temperatures will likely result in an early snow melt through May 2024.
➢ Wheat planting: Farmers are expected to use the spring window to complete the wheat planting process this season. The success of the coming cropping season depends on timely and welldistributed precipitation in the coming months & the availability of irrigation water in the summertime. ➢ Rangeland vegetative conditions during the 2024 spring (March-May) are expected to improve and most likely to be near average in most areas, with some below-average areas due to the persistence of current conditions and above-average temperatures. During summer (JuneSeptember), most areas will turn to below-average, due to below-average cumulative 2023/24 precipitation, above-average temperatures, or both.
➢ Possible risks: The combination of average to above-average precipitation and above-average temperatures during the remainder of the 2023/24 agricultural season may elevate the risk of yellow rust affecting the yield and productivity of wheat in the eastern, northern, northeastern, and southern provinces. Moreover, concerns exist about the risk of locust infestation in crops and pasture areas. The anticipated near-average to average cumulative precipitation in 2024 will enhance vegetation conditions, which may facilitate the growth of locust populations in the coming months, particularly in the northern and northeastern provinces.
➢ Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI): A worsen NDVI mainly in northern and eastern and central parts of the country is seen. The land surface Temperature (LST) has reduced significantly in the southern and western. This means that due to the negative LST the vegetation could be impacted.
➢ Soil Moisture: Currently below average and better than last year but expected to improve given soil moisture and expected precipitation.
➢ Exchange Rate: After its surge in January 2022, the value of AFN started to consistently appreciate against the USD during the year 2023 and remains relatively stable, hovering around AFN 70-74 per USD since November 2023. The monthly average exchange rate between AFN and USD was recorded at AFN 71.4 per 1 USD during March 2024 and the weekly average rate in third week of April stands at AFN 72.1 per 1USD.

claims.sentence: [meeting minutes] early warning information working group (ewiwg) presented comprehensive overview early warning information cluster partners.

title: Afghanistan: Minutes of FSAC Monthly Meeting (24 April 2024) [Meeting Minutes] 
 content: The Early Warning Information Working Group (EWIWG) presented a comprehensive overview of early warning information to the cluster partners. Here are the key highlights from the presentation.
➢ Precipitation: rainfall for the 2023/24 winter wet season, from October 2023 to March 2024, is most likely to be below average, with areas with average values. Average precipitation is most likely to occur from March to May 2024, during the wet spring season. Spring rains are expected to have normal timing and distribution, with minimal adverse impact on typical agricultural activities through flooding.
➢ Temperature: Above average daily mean temperatures are most likely through September 2024. Extreme temperatures during May-July and July-September (upper quintile) are 2-3 times more likely than climatology. The consequences of the above-average temperature may be moisture stress in rainfed crops and rangelands and reduced water availability, mainly in the downstream areas that may experience extended dry spells.
➢ Snow Water Volumes: Given below-average antecedent precipitation and current snow water volumes, below-average snow water volumes are expected in the coming months. However, there is more snow than in 2023, given recent accumulations due to above-average precipitation in February and March. Above-average temperatures will likely result in an early snow melt through May 2024.
➢ Wheat planting: Farmers are expected to use the spring window to complete the wheat planting process this season. The success of the coming cropping season depends on timely and welldistributed precipitation in the coming months & the availability of irrigation water in the summertime. ➢ Rangeland vegetative conditions during the 2024 spring (March-May) are expected to improve and most likely to be near average in most areas, with some below-average areas due to the persistence of current conditions and above-average temperatures. During summer (JuneSeptember), most areas will turn to below-average, due to below-average cumulative 2023/24 precipitation, above-average temperatures, or both.

Moreover, concerns exist about the risk of locust infestation in crops and pasture areas. The monthly average exchange rate between AFN and USD was recorded at AFN 71.4 per 1 USD during March 2024 and the weekly average rate in third week of April stands at AFN 72.1 per 1USD.

However, there is more snow than in 2023, given recent accumulations due to above-average precipitation in February and March. Above-average temperatures will likely result in an early snow melt through May 2024.

What were the immediate and long-term im.summary:
The recent flash floods in Afghanistan, particularly impacting provinces like Baghlan, Badakhshan, Ghor, Herat, Faryab, and Takhar, caused immediate and widespread devastation [1][2]. Immediately, the floods resulted in over 330 fatalities and hundreds of injuries, with children disproportionately represented among the casualties [1][2]. Thousands of homes were damaged or destroyed, alongside significant damage to agricultural land, livestock, and critical infrastructure, including roads, schools, and health centers [1][2]. The floods struck populations already facing high levels of food insecurity and economic hardship, pushing communities to the brink of famine, especially in Baghlan [1][3].

In the long term, these natural disasters have severely exacerbated Afghanistan's existing humanitarian crisis, with a particular impact on children [2]. The widespread destruction of homes and livelihoods has led to displacement and a loss of access to essential services, including health care, clean water, sanitation, and education [2][3]. This critical blow to agriculture and food production further worsens food insecurity for millions already suffering from severe hunger, increasing the risks of malnutrition and waterborne diseases [2][3]. Children, a particularly vulnerable group, are also experiencing trauma, increased displacement, and heightened risks of exploitation following the floods [2]. Humanitarian organizations, including OCHA, UNICEF, and the World Food Programme, are providing crucial assistance, such as food aid, to address the immediate and ongoing needs of the affected populations [1][2][3].

metadata.title: Afghanistan: Minutes of FSAC Monthly Meeting (17 January 2024) [Meeting Minutes]
metadata.content:
title: Afghanistan: Minutes of FSAC Monthly Meeting (17 January 2024) [Meeting Minutes] 
 content: The members of EWIMWG delivered a comprehensive presentation on early warning information to the cluster partners. Below, you'll find the key highlights from the pivotal presentation.
- Precipitation: According to all models, For January 2023- Marh 2024, there are most likely chance of above average precipitation in most of Afghanistan. However, rainfall analysis for the period since 1 November shows below-average precipitation over the country (10-100mm anomalies, locally higher in the West. o Snow: Negative snow depth, and snow water equivalent anomalies are greatest in the Northeast as well as along the northern slopes of the central mountains. As a result, abnormal dryness is placed in northern, eastern, and northeastern Afghanistan.
- Temperature: During the outlook period, 7-day mean maximum temperatures are forecasted to be well above average across Afghanistan. During Jan-Mar 2024, various climate models have consistently forecasted above-average e temperatures during this outlook period.
- Price: WFP in-kind food basket in Afghani has shown a continuous decline since reaching its peak in June 2022 up to September 2023, but had a slight increase in October 2023, followed by a decrease in December 2023. The Food Security and Agriculture Cluster (FSAC) food basket used for cash-based transfers (CBTs).
The national average AFN price of FSAC basket in the month of December 2023 was 2.6 percent lower than the last month and higher by 24 percent compared to the pre– Covid period (second week of March 2020). The national average USD price decreased negligibly by 1.5 percent in the month of December 2023 compared to the previous month, 5 percent lower than the price one year ago and 13 percent higher compared to month of June 2021 (before the recent conflicts and political change).

claims.sentence: [meeting minutes] members ewimwg delivered comprehensive presentation early warning information cluster partners.

metadata.title: Afghanistan: Minutes of FSAC Monthly Meeting (24 April 2024) [Meeting Minutes]
metadata.content:
title: Afghanistan: Minutes of FSAC Monthly Meeting (24 April 2024) [Meeting Minutes] 
 content: The Early Warning Information Working Group (EWIWG) presented a comprehensive overview of early warning information to the cluster partners. Here are the key highlights from the presentation.
➢ Precipitation: rainfall for the 2023/24 winter wet season, from October 2023 to March 2024, is most likely to be below average, with areas with average values. Average precipitation is most likely to occur from March to May 2024, during the wet spring season. Spring rains are expected to have normal timing and distribution, with minimal adverse impact on typical agricultural activities through flooding.
➢ Temperature: Above average daily mean temperatures are most likely through September 2024. Extreme temperatures during May-July and July-September (upper quintile) are 2-3 times more likely than climatology. The consequences of the above-average temperature may be moisture stress in rainfed crops and rangelands and reduced water availability, mainly in the downstream areas that may experience extended dry spells.
➢ Snow Water Volumes: Given below-average antecedent precipitation and current snow water volumes, below-average snow water volumes are expected in the coming months. However, there is more snow than in 2023, given recent accumulations due to above-average precipitation in February and March. Above-average temperatures will likely result in an early snow melt through May 2024.
➢ Wheat planting: Farmers are expected to use the spring window to complete the wheat planting process this season. The success of the coming cropping season depends on timely and welldistributed precipitation in the coming months & the availability of irrigation water in the summertime. ➢ Rangeland vegetative conditions during the 2024 spring (March-May) are expected to improve and most likely to be near average in most areas, with some below-average areas due to the persistence of current conditions and above-average temperatures. During summer (JuneSeptember), most areas will turn to below-average, due to below-average cumulative 2023/24 precipitation, above-average temperatures, or both.
➢ Possible risks: The combination of average to above-average precipitation and above-average temperatures during the remainder of the 2023/24 agricultural season may elevate the risk of yellow rust affecting the yield and productivity of wheat in the eastern, northern, northeastern, and southern provinces. Moreover, concerns exist about the risk of locust infestation in crops and pasture areas. The anticipated near-average to average cumulative precipitation in 2024 will enhance vegetation conditions, which may facilitate the growth of locust populations in the coming months, particularly in the northern and northeastern provinces.
➢ Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI): A worsen NDVI mainly in northern and eastern and central parts of the country is seen. The land surface Temperature (LST) has reduced significantly in the southern and western. This means that due to the negative LST the vegetation could be impacted.
➢ Soil Moisture: Currently below average and better than last year but expected to improve given soil moisture and expected precipitation.
➢ Exchange Rate: After its surge in January 2022, the value of AFN started to consistently appreciate against the USD during the year 2023 and remains relatively stable, hovering around AFN 70-74 per USD since November 2023. The monthly average exchange rate between AFN and USD was recorded at AFN 71.4 per 1 USD during March 2024 and the weekly average rate in third week of April stands at AFN 72.1 per 1USD.

claims.sentence: [meeting minutes] early warning information working group (ewiwg) presented comprehensive overview early warning information cluster partners.

Spring rains are expected to have normal timing and distribution, with minimal adverse impact on typical agricultural activities through flooding.
➢ Temperature: Above average daily mean temperatures are most likely through September 2024. Extreme temperatures during May-July and July-September (upper quintile) are 2-3 times more likely than climatology. The consequences of the above-average temperature may be moisture stress in rainfed crops and rangelands and reduced water availability, mainly in the downstream areas that may experience extended dry spells.
➢ Snow Water Volumes: Given below-average antecedent precipitation and current snow water volumes, below-average snow water volumes are expected in the coming months. However, there is more snow than in 2023, given recent accumulations due to above-average precipitation in February and March. Above-average temperatures will likely result in an early snow melt through May 2024.
➢ Wheat planting: Farmers are expected to use the spring window to complete the wheat planting process this season. The success of the coming cropping season depends on timely and welldistributed precipitation in the coming months & the availability of irrigation water in the summertime. ➢ Rangeland vegetative conditions during the 2024 spring (March-May) are expected to improve and most likely to be near average in most areas, with some below-average areas due to the persistence of current conditions and above-average temperatures. During summer (JuneSeptember), most areas will turn to below-average, due to below-average cumulative 2023/24 precipitation, above-average temperatures, or both.
➢ Possible risks: The combination of average to above-average precipitation and above-average temperatures during the remainder of the 2023/24 agricultural season may elevate the risk of yellow rust affecting the yield and productivity of wheat in the eastern, northern, northeastern, and southern provinces. Moreover, concerns exist about the risk of locust infestation in crops and pasture areas. The anticipated near-average to average cumulative precipitation in 2024 will enhance vegetation conditions, which may facilitate the growth of locust populations in the coming months, particularly in the northern and northeastern provinces.
➢ Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI): A worsen NDVI mainly in northern and eastern and central parts of the country is seen. The land surface Temperature (LST) has reduced significantly in the southern and western. This means that due to the negative LST the vegetation could be impacted.
➢ Soil Moisture: Currently below average and better than last year but expected to improve given soil moisture and expected precipitation.
➢ Exchange Rate: After its surge in January 2022, the value of AFN started to consistently appreciate against the USD during the year 2023 and remains relatively stable, hovering around AFN 70-74 per USD since November 2023. The monthly average exchange rate between AFN and USD was recorded at AFN 71.4 per 1 USD during March 2024 and the weekly average rate in third week of April stands at AFN 72.1 per 1USD.

claims.sentence: anticipated near-average average cumulative precipitation 2024 enhance vegetation conditions, may facilitate growth locust populations coming months, particularly northern northeastern provinces.

are some strategic questions that could.summary:
For the FSAC monthly meeting, strategic questions regarding early warning information for floods in Afghanistan could focus on several critical areas. A primary concern is identifying and addressing the significant gaps in existing early warning, preparedness, and response capacities, noting that current systems are often fragmented and lack comprehensive coverage, especially in remote areas [5]. It is crucial to consider how to ensure that early warning systems for floods are community-centric, reliable, accessible, and inclusive, actively involving the most vulnerable populations [3].

Another key strategic question involves the necessary investments in robust infrastructure, capacity building, and improved data collection and analysis to strengthen these early warning systems [5]. Furthermore, FSAC should discuss how to foster clear communication protocols and enhance multi-stakeholder collaboration to ensure that early warnings effectively translate into anticipatory action for floods [3]. Given the increased frequency and intensity of floods due to climate change, integrating climate adaptation and disaster risk reduction (DRR) into humanitarian and development planning, informed by early warning information, is a critical strategic consideration [6].

The meeting could also explore how to improve FSAC's capacity for anticipatory action based on early warning to more effectively mitigate the impacts of floods [6]. Finally, a strategic discussion point should involve how to advocate for sustained funding and donor flexibility to address the humanitarian needs and significant funding gaps for early warning and preparedness initiatives in Afghanistan, amidst ongoing resource limitations [1][4][5].

claims.sentence: afghanistan: minutes fsac monthly meeting (17 january 2024)

metadata.title: Afghanistan: Minutes of FSAC Monthly Meeting (17 January 2024) [Meeting Minutes]
metadata.content:
title: Afghanistan: Minutes of FSAC Monthly Meeting (17 January 2024) [Meeting Minutes] 
 content: The members of EWIMWG delivered a comprehensive presentation on early warning information to the cluster partners. Below, you'll find the key highlights from the pivotal presentation.
- Precipitation: According to all models, For January 2023- Marh 2024, there are most likely chance of above average precipitation in most of Afghanistan. However, rainfall analysis for the period since 1 November shows below-average precipitation over the country (10-100mm anomalies, locally higher in the West. o Snow: Negative snow depth, and snow water equivalent anomalies are greatest in the Northeast as well as along the northern slopes of the central mountains. As a result, abnormal dryness is placed in northern, eastern, and northeastern Afghanistan.
- Temperature: During the outlook period, 7-day mean maximum temperatures are forecasted to be well above average across Afghanistan. During Jan-Mar 2024, various climate models have consistently forecasted above-average e temperatures during this outlook period.
- Price: WFP in-kind food basket in Afghani has shown a continuous decline since reaching its peak in June 2022 up to September 2023, but had a slight increase in October 2023, followed by a decrease in December 2023. The Food Security and Agriculture Cluster (FSAC) food basket used for cash-based transfers (CBTs).
The national average AFN price of FSAC basket in the month of December 2023 was 2.6 percent lower than the last month and higher by 24 percent compared to the pre– Covid period (second week of March 2020). The national average USD price decreased negligibly by 1.5 percent in the month of December 2023 compared to the previous month, 5 percent lower than the price one year ago and 13 percent higher compared to month of June 2021 (before the recent conflicts and political change).

claims.sentence: [meeting minutes] members ewimwg delivered comprehensive presentation early warning information cluster partners.

metadata.title: Afghanistan: Minutes of FSAC Monthly Meeting (24 April 2024) [Meeting Minutes]
metadata.content:
title: Afghanistan: Minutes of FSAC Monthly Meeting (24 April 2024) [Meeting Minutes] 
 content: The Early Warning Information Working Group (EWIWG) presented a comprehensive overview of early warning information to the cluster partners. Here are the key highlights from the presentation.
➢ Precipitation: rainfall for the 2023/24 winter wet season, from October 2023 to March 2024, is most likely to be below average, with areas with average values. Average precipitation is most likely to occur from March to May 2024, during the wet spring season. Spring rains are expected to have normal timing and distribution, with minimal adverse impact on typical agricultural activities through flooding.
➢ Temperature: Above average daily mean temperatures are most likely through September 2024. Extreme temperatures during May-July and July-September (upper quintile) are 2-3 times more likely than climatology. The consequences of the above-average temperature may be moisture stress in rainfed crops and rangelands and reduced water availability, mainly in the downstream areas that may experience extended dry spells.
➢ Snow Water Volumes: Given below-average antecedent precipitation and current snow water volumes, below-average snow water volumes are expected in the coming months. However, there is more snow than in 2023, given recent accumulations due to above-average precipitation in February and March. Above-average temperatures will likely result in an early snow melt through May 2024.
➢ Wheat planting: Farmers are expected to use the spring window to complete the wheat planting process this season. The success of the coming cropping season depends on timely and welldistributed precipitation in the coming months & the availability of irrigation water in the summertime. ➢ Rangeland vegetative conditions during the 2024 spring (March-May) are expected to improve and most likely to be near average in most areas, with some below-average areas due to the persistence of current conditions and above-average temperatures. During summer (JuneSeptember), most areas will turn to below-average, due to below-average cumulative 2023/24 precipitation, above-average temperatures, or both.
➢ Possible risks: The combination of average to above-average precipitation and above-average temperatures during the remainder of the 2023/24 agricultural season may elevate the risk of yellow rust affecting the yield and productivity of wheat in the eastern, northern, northeastern, and southern provinces. Moreover, concerns exist about the risk of locust infestation in crops and pasture areas. The anticipated near-average to average cumulative precipitation in 2024 will enhance vegetation conditions, which may facilitate the growth of locust populations in the coming months, particularly in the northern and northeastern provinces.
➢ Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI): A worsen NDVI mainly in northern and eastern and central parts of the country is seen. The land surface Temperature (LST) has reduced significantly in the southern and western. This means that due to the negative LST the vegetation could be impacted.
➢ Soil Moisture: Currently below average and better than last year but expected to improve given soil moisture and expected precipitation.
➢ Exchange Rate: After its surge in January 2022, the value of AFN started to consistently appreciate against the USD during the year 2023 and remains relatively stable, hovering around AFN 70-74 per USD since November 2023. The monthly average exchange rate between AFN and USD was recorded at AFN 71.4 per 1 USD during March 2024 and the weekly average rate in third week of April stands at AFN 72.1 per 1USD.

claims.sentence: [meeting minutes] early warning information working group (ewiwg) presented comprehensive overview early warning information cluster partners.

 content: The Early Warning Information Working Group (EWIWG) presented a comprehensive overview of early warning information to the cluster partners. Here are the key highlights from the presentation.
➢ Precipitation: rainfall for the 2023/24 winter wet season, from October 2023 to March 2024, is most likely to be below average, with areas with average values. Average precipitation is most likely to occur from March to May 2024, during the wet spring season. Spring rains are expected to have normal timing and distribution, with minimal adverse impact on typical agricultural activities through flooding.
➢ Temperature: Above average daily mean temperatures are most likely through September 2024. Extreme temperatures during May-July and July-September (upper quintile) are 2-3 times more likely than climatology. The consequences of the above-average temperature may be moisture stress in rainfed crops and rangelands and reduced water availability, mainly in the downstream areas that may experience extended dry spells.
➢ Snow Water Volumes: Given below-average antecedent precipitation and current snow water volumes, below-average snow water volumes are expected in the coming months. However, there is more snow than in 2023, given recent accumulations due to above-average precipitation in February and March. Above-average temperatures will likely result in an early snow melt through May 2024.
➢ Wheat planting: Farmers are expected to use the spring window to complete the wheat planting process this season. The success of the coming cropping season depends on timely and welldistributed precipitation in the coming months & the availability of irrigation water in the summertime. ➢ Rangeland vegetative conditions during the 2024 spring (March-May) are expected to improve and most likely to be near average in most areas, with some below-average areas due to the persistence of current conditions and above-average temperatures. During summer (JuneSeptember), most areas will turn to below-average, due to below-average cumulative 2023/24 precipitation, above-average temperatures, or both.
➢ Possible risks: The combination of average to above-average precipitation and above-average temperatures during the remainder of the 2023/24 agricultural season may elevate the risk of yellow rust affecting the yield and productivity of wheat in the eastern, northern, northeastern, and southern provinces. Moreover, concerns exist about the risk of locust infestation in crops and pasture areas. The anticipated near-average to average cumulative precipitation in 2024 will enhance vegetation conditions, which may facilitate the growth of locust populations in the coming months, particularly in the northern and northeastern provinces.
➢ Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI): A worsen NDVI mainly in northern and eastern and central parts of the country is seen. The land surface Temperature (LST) has reduced significantly in the southern and western. This means that due to the negative LST the vegetation could be impacted.
➢ Soil Moisture: Currently below average and better than last year but expected to improve given soil moisture and expected precipitation.
➢ Exchange Rate: After its surge in January 2022, the value of AFN started to consistently appreciate against the USD during the year 2023 and remains relatively stable, hovering around AFN 70-74 per USD since November 2023. The monthly average exchange rate between AFN and USD was recorded at AFN 71.4 per 1 USD during March 2024 and the weekly average rate in third week of April stands at AFN 72.1 per 1USD.

claims.sentence: rangeland vegetative conditions 2024 spring (march-may) expected improve likely near average areas, below-average areas due persistence current conditions above-average temperatures.

➢ Soil Moisture: Currently below average and better than last year but expected to improve given soil moisture and expected precipitation.

 content: The Early Warning Information Working Group (EWIWG) presented a comprehensive overview of early warning information to the cluster partners. Here are the key highlights from the presentation.
➢ Precipitation: rainfall for the 2023/24 winter wet season, from October 2023 to March 2024, is most likely to be below average, with areas with average values. Spring rains are expected to have normal timing and distribution, with minimal adverse impact on typical agricultural activities through flooding.
➢ Temperature: Above average daily mean temperatures are most likely through September 2024. Extreme temperatures during May-July and July-September (upper quintile) are 2-3 times more likely than climatology. The consequences of the above-average temperature may be moisture stress in rainfed crops and rangelands and reduced water availability, mainly in the downstream areas that may experience extended dry spells.
➢ Snow Water Volumes: Given below-average antecedent precipitation and current snow water volumes, below-average snow water volumes are expected in the coming months. However, there is more snow than in 2023, given recent accumulations due to above-average precipitation in February and March. Moreover, concerns exist about the risk of locust infestation in crops and pasture areas. The anticipated near-average to average cumulative precipitation in 2024 will enhance vegetation conditions, which may facilitate the growth of locust populations in the coming months, particularly in the northern and northeastern provinces.
➢ Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI): A worsen NDVI mainly in northern and eastern and central parts of the country is seen. The land surface Temperature (LST) has reduced significantly in the southern and western. This means that due to the negative LST the vegetation could be impacted.
➢ Soil Moisture: Currently below average and better than last year but expected to improve given soil moisture and expected precipitation.
➢ Exchange Rate: After its surge in January 2022, the value of AFN started to consistently appreciate against the USD during the year 2023 and remains relatively stable, hovering around AFN 70-74 per USD since November 2023. The monthly average exchange rate between AFN and USD was recorded at AFN 71.4 per 1 USD during March 2024 and the weekly average rate in third week of April stands at AFN 72.1 per 1USD.

How can improvements implemented in the.summary:
Improvements implemented in the FSAC monthly meeting can be effective by directly addressing the previous issues of discussions repeating without resolution and disengaged participants [1]. The FSAC plans to enhance meeting effectiveness through a new approach centered on clear objectives and actionable outcomes, ensuring discussions lead to concrete actions and problem resolution [2]. A structured agenda will be crucial for productivity, prioritizing key issues and allocating specific time to cover all critical topics efficiently [3].

Effectiveness will further stem from greater accountability, where each action item will be assigned to a responsible person with a deadline, supported by regular follow-ups to track progress and address any bottlenecks [4]. Encouraging active participant engagement is vital, as creating an open environment where all members can contribute ideas and solutions will boost problem-solving capabilities [5]. Additionally, training for meeting facilitators will improve discussion management, enabling them to guide conversations, prevent digressions, and maintain focus on objectives, thereby leading to more efficient and productive meetings [6]. Collectively, these strategic enhancements aim to transform the monthly meetings into a more impactful forum that successfully addresses and resolves issues [2].

metadata.title: Afghanistan: Minutes of FSAC Monthly Meeting (17 January 2024) [Meeting Minutes]
metadata.content:
title: Afghanistan: Minutes of FSAC Monthly Meeting (17 January 2024) [Meeting Minutes] 
 content: The members of EWIMWG delivered a comprehensive presentation on early warning information to the cluster partners. Below, you'll find the key highlights from the pivotal presentation.
- Precipitation: According to all models, For January 2023- Marh 2024, there are most likely chance of above average precipitation in most of Afghanistan. However, rainfall analysis for the period since 1 November shows below-average precipitation over the country (10-100mm anomalies, locally higher in the West. o Snow: Negative snow depth, and snow water equivalent anomalies are greatest in the Northeast as well as along the northern slopes of the central mountains. As a result, abnormal dryness is placed in northern, eastern, and northeastern Afghanistan.
- Temperature: During the outlook period, 7-day mean maximum temperatures are forecasted to be well above average across Afghanistan. During Jan-Mar 2024, various climate models have consistently forecasted above-average e temperatures during this outlook period.
- Price: WFP in-kind food basket in Afghani has shown a continuous decline since reaching its peak in June 2022 up to September 2023, but had a slight increase in October 2023, followed by a decrease in December 2023. The Food Security and Agriculture Cluster (FSAC) food basket used for cash-based transfers (CBTs).
The national average AFN price of FSAC basket in the month of December 2023 was 2.6 percent lower than the last month and higher by 24 percent compared to the pre– Covid period (second week of March 2020). The national average USD price decreased negligibly by 1.5 percent in the month of December 2023 compared to the previous month, 5 percent lower than the price one year ago and 13 percent higher compared to month of June 2021 (before the recent conflicts and political change).

claims.sentence: [meeting minutes] members ewimwg delivered comprehensive presentation early warning information cluster partners.

title: Afghanistan: Minutes of FSAC Monthly Meeting (17 January 2024) [Meeting Minutes] 
 content: The members of EWIMWG delivered a comprehensive presentation on early warning information to the cluster partners. Below, you'll find the key highlights from the pivotal presentation.
- Precipitation: According to all models, For January 2023- Marh 2024, there are most likely chance of above average precipitation in most of Afghanistan. However, rainfall analysis for the period since 1 November shows below-average precipitation over the country (10-100mm anomalies, locally higher in the West. o Snow: Negative snow depth, and snow water equivalent anomalies are greatest in the Northeast as well as along the northern slopes of the central mountains. As a result, abnormal dryness is placed in northern, eastern, and northeastern Afghanistan.
- Temperature: During the outlook period, 7-day mean maximum temperatures are forecasted to be well above average across Afghanistan. During Jan-Mar 2024, various climate models have consistently forecasted above-average e temperatures during this outlook period.
- Price: WFP in-kind food basket in Afghani has shown a continuous decline since reaching its peak in June 2022 up to September 2023, but had a slight increase in October 2023, followed by a decrease in December 2023. The Food Security and Agriculture Cluster (FSAC) food basket used for cash-based transfers (CBTs).
The national average AFN price of FSAC basket in the month of December 2023 was 2.6 percent lower than the last month and higher by 24 percent compared to the pre– Covid period (second week of March 2020). The national average USD price decreased negligibly by 1.5 percent in the month of December 2023 compared to the previous month, 5 percent lower than the price one year ago and 13 percent higher compared to month of June 2021 (before the recent conflicts and political change).

claims.sentence: afghanistan: minutes fsac monthly meeting (24 april 2024)

metadata.title: Afghanistan: Minutes of FSAC Monthly Meeting (24 April 2024) [Meeting Minutes]
metadata.content:
title: Afghanistan: Minutes of FSAC Monthly Meeting (24 April 2024) [Meeting Minutes] 
 content: The Early Warning Information Working Group (EWIWG) presented a comprehensive overview of early warning information to the cluster partners. Here are the key highlights from the presentation.
➢ Precipitation: rainfall for the 2023/24 winter wet season, from October 2023 to March 2024, is most likely to be below average, with areas with average values. Average precipitation is most likely to occur from March to May 2024, during the wet spring season. Spring rains are expected to have normal timing and distribution, with minimal adverse impact on typical agricultural activities through flooding.
➢ Temperature: Above average daily mean temperatures are most likely through September 2024. Extreme temperatures during May-July and July-September (upper quintile) are 2-3 times more likely than climatology. The consequences of the above-average temperature may be moisture stress in rainfed crops and rangelands and reduced water availability, mainly in the downstream areas that may experience extended dry spells.
➢ Snow Water Volumes: Given below-average antecedent precipitation and current snow water volumes, below-average snow water volumes are expected in the coming months. However, there is more snow than in 2023, given recent accumulations due to above-average precipitation in February and March. Above-average temperatures will likely result in an early snow melt through May 2024.
➢ Wheat planting: Farmers are expected to use the spring window to complete the wheat planting process this season. The success of the coming cropping season depends on timely and welldistributed precipitation in the coming months & the availability of irrigation water in the summertime. ➢ Rangeland vegetative conditions during the 2024 spring (March-May) are expected to improve and most likely to be near average in most areas, with some below-average areas due to the persistence of current conditions and above-average temperatures. During summer (JuneSeptember), most areas will turn to below-average, due to below-average cumulative 2023/24 precipitation, above-average temperatures, or both.
➢ Possible risks: The combination of average to above-average precipitation and above-average temperatures during the remainder of the 2023/24 agricultural season may elevate the risk of yellow rust affecting the yield and productivity of wheat in the eastern, northern, northeastern, and southern provinces. Moreover, concerns exist about the risk of locust infestation in crops and pasture areas. The anticipated near-average to average cumulative precipitation in 2024 will enhance vegetation conditions, which may facilitate the growth of locust populations in the coming months, particularly in the northern and northeastern provinces.
➢ Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI): A worsen NDVI mainly in northern and eastern and central parts of the country is seen. The land surface Temperature (LST) has reduced significantly in the southern and western. This means that due to the negative LST the vegetation could be impacted.
➢ Soil Moisture: Currently below average and better than last year but expected to improve given soil moisture and expected precipitation.
➢ Exchange Rate: After its surge in January 2022, the value of AFN started to consistently appreciate against the USD during the year 2023 and remains relatively stable, hovering around AFN 70-74 per USD since November 2023. The monthly average exchange rate between AFN and USD was recorded at AFN 71.4 per 1 USD during March 2024 and the weekly average rate in third week of April stands at AFN 72.1 per 1USD.

claims.sentence: [meeting minutes] early warning information working group (ewiwg) presented comprehensive overview early warning information cluster partners.

title: Afghanistan: Minutes of FSAC Monthly Meeting (24 April 2024) [Meeting Minutes] 
 content: The Early Warning Information Working Group (EWIWG) presented a comprehensive overview of early warning information to the cluster partners. Here are the key highlights from the presentation.
➢ Precipitation: rainfall for the 2023/24 winter wet season, from October 2023 to March 2024, is most likely to be below average, with areas with average values. Average precipitation is most likely to occur from March to May 2024, during the wet spring season. Spring rains are expected to have normal timing and distribution, with minimal adverse impact on typical agricultural activities through flooding.
➢ Temperature: Above average daily mean temperatures are most likely through September 2024. Extreme temperatures during May-July and July-September (upper quintile) are 2-3 times more likely than climatology. The consequences of the above-average temperature may be moisture stress in rainfed crops and rangelands and reduced water availability, mainly in the downstream areas that may experience extended dry spells.
➢ Snow Water Volumes: Given below-average antecedent precipitation and current snow water volumes, below-average snow water volumes are expected in the coming months. However, there is more snow than in 2023, given recent accumulations due to above-average precipitation in February and March. Above-average temperatures will likely result in an early snow melt through May 2024.
➢ Wheat planting: Farmers are expected to use the spring window to complete the wheat planting process this season. The success of the coming cropping season depends on timely and welldistributed precipitation in the coming months & the availability of irrigation water in the summertime. ➢ Rangeland vegetative conditions during the 2024 spring (March-May) are expected to improve and most likely to be near average in most areas, with some below-average areas due to the persistence of current conditions and above-average temperatures. During summer (JuneSeptember), most areas will turn to below-average, due to below-average cumulative 2023/24 precipitation, above-average temperatures, or both.
➢ Possible risks: The combination of average to above-average precipitation and above-average temperatures during the remainder of the 2023/24 agricultural season may elevate the risk of yellow rust affecting the yield and productivity of wheat in the eastern, northern, northeastern, and southern provinces. Moreover, concerns exist about the risk of locust infestation in crops and pasture areas. The anticipated near-average to average cumulative precipitation in 2024 will enhance vegetation conditions, which may facilitate the growth of locust populations in the coming months, particularly in the northern and northeastern provinces.
➢ Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI): A worsen NDVI mainly in northern and eastern and central parts of the country is seen. The land surface Temperature (LST) has reduced significantly in the southern and western. This means that due to the negative LST the vegetation could be impacted.
➢ Soil Moisture: Currently below average and better than last year but expected to improve given soil moisture and expected precipitation.
➢ Exchange Rate: After its surge in January 2022, the value of AFN started to consistently appreciate against the USD during the year 2023 and remains relatively stable, hovering around AFN 70-74 per USD since November 2023. The monthly average exchange rate between AFN and USD was recorded at AFN 71.4 per 1 USD during March 2024 and the weekly average rate in third week of April stands at AFN 72.1 per 1USD.

claims.sentence: however, snow 2023, given recent accumulations due above-average precipitation february march.

What data collection methodologies were.summary:
Early warning information in Afghanistan has historically been gathered using diverse methodologies, often necessitated by challenging security environments. Initially, on-the-ground observation, carried out by local staff and community leaders, provided crucial insights, although this information was often fragmented, anecdotal, and potentially biased [1]. Following events such as the Taliban takeover, which reduced on-the-ground presence, there was an increased reliance on local networks, remote monitoring, and satellite imagery [2]. Other employed methodologies included the use of local third-party monitors, digital tools, mobile data collection, and Geographic Information Systems (GIS) [3][4][5]. Humanitarian needs assessments were also conducted, although their direct execution became increasingly difficult in insecure environments [4]. Additionally, community-based early warning systems have been utilized to gather localized information [5].

To enhance the accuracy and timeliness of these data collection methodologies, several improvements are recommended. A critical approach involves better triangulation of data, drawing from diverse sources to overcome the inherent limitations and potential biases of any single method [1][4]. Combining various methodologies, such as integrating remote monitoring with insights from local third-party monitors, can provide more nuanced and reliable data [3]. Investing in local capacity building and fostering local ownership of data collection are crucial steps for improving both accuracy and sustainability [3][5]. Furthermore, ensuring a greater reliance on diverse, real-time data sources, coupled with robust community engagement, is essential for timely early warning [2]. The effective utilization of advanced digital tools, mobile applications, and remote sensing technologies can significantly improve the efficiency and breadth of data collection and analysis [1][5]. Finally, establishing strong data validation processes and feedback mechanisms is vital to verify the reliability of the collected information [5].

metadata.title: Afghanistan: Minutes of FSAC Monthly Meeting (17 January 2024) [Meeting Minutes]
metadata.content:
title: Afghanistan: Minutes of FSAC Monthly Meeting (17 January 2024) [Meeting Minutes] 
 content: The members of EWIMWG delivered a comprehensive presentation on early warning information to the cluster partners. Below, you'll find the key highlights from the pivotal presentation.
- Precipitation: According to all models, For January 2023- Marh 2024, there are most likely chance of above average precipitation in most of Afghanistan. However, rainfall analysis for the period since 1 November shows below-average precipitation over the country (10-100mm anomalies, locally higher in the West. o Snow: Negative snow depth, and snow water equivalent anomalies are greatest in the Northeast as well as along the northern slopes of the central mountains. As a result, abnormal dryness is placed in northern, eastern, and northeastern Afghanistan.
- Temperature: During the outlook period, 7-day mean maximum temperatures are forecasted to be well above average across Afghanistan. During Jan-Mar 2024, various climate models have consistently forecasted above-average e temperatures during this outlook period.
- Price: WFP in-kind food basket in Afghani has shown a continuous decline since reaching its peak in June 2022 up to September 2023, but had a slight increase in October 2023, followed by a decrease in December 2023. The Food Security and Agriculture Cluster (FSAC) food basket used for cash-based transfers (CBTs).
The national average AFN price of FSAC basket in the month of December 2023 was 2.6 percent lower than the last month and higher by 24 percent compared to the pre– Covid period (second week of March 2020). The national average USD price decreased negligibly by 1.5 percent in the month of December 2023 compared to the previous month, 5 percent lower than the price one year ago and 13 percent higher compared to month of June 2021 (before the recent conflicts and political change).

metadata.title: Afghanistan: Minutes of FSAC Monthly Meeting (24 April 2024) [Meeting Minutes]
metadata.content:
title: Afghanistan: Minutes of FSAC Monthly Meeting (24 April 2024) [Meeting Minutes] 
 content: The Early Warning Information Working Group (EWIWG) presented a comprehensive overview of early warning information to the cluster partners. Here are the key highlights from the presentation.
➢ Precipitation: rainfall for the 2023/24 winter wet season, from October 2023 to March 2024, is most likely to be below average, with areas with average values. Average precipitation is most likely to occur from March to May 2024, during the wet spring season. Spring rains are expected to have normal timing and distribution, with minimal adverse impact on typical agricultural activities through flooding.
➢ Temperature: Above average daily mean temperatures are most likely through September 2024. Extreme temperatures during May-July and July-September (upper quintile) are 2-3 times more likely than climatology. The consequences of the above-average temperature may be moisture stress in rainfed crops and rangelands and reduced water availability, mainly in the downstream areas that may experience extended dry spells.
➢ Snow Water Volumes: Given below-average antecedent precipitation and current snow water volumes, below-average snow water volumes are expected in the coming months. However, there is more snow than in 2023, given recent accumulations due to above-average precipitation in February and March. Above-average temperatures will likely result in an early snow melt through May 2024.
➢ Wheat planting: Farmers are expected to use the spring window to complete the wheat planting process this season. The success of the coming cropping season depends on timely and welldistributed precipitation in the coming months & the availability of irrigation water in the summertime. ➢ Rangeland vegetative conditions during the 2024 spring (March-May) are expected to improve and most likely to be near average in most areas, with some below-average areas due to the persistence of current conditions and above-average temperatures. During summer (JuneSeptember), most areas will turn to below-average, due to below-average cumulative 2023/24 precipitation, above-average temperatures, or both.
➢ Possible risks: The combination of average to above-average precipitation and above-average temperatures during the remainder of the 2023/24 agricultural season may elevate the risk of yellow rust affecting the yield and productivity of wheat in the eastern, northern, northeastern, and southern provinces. Moreover, concerns exist about the risk of locust infestation in crops and pasture areas. The anticipated near-average to average cumulative precipitation in 2024 will enhance vegetation conditions, which may facilitate the growth of locust populations in the coming months, particularly in the northern and northeastern provinces.
➢ Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI): A worsen NDVI mainly in northern and eastern and central parts of the country is seen. The land surface Temperature (LST) has reduced significantly in the southern and western. This means that due to the negative LST the vegetation could be impacted.
➢ Soil Moisture: Currently below average and better than last year but expected to improve given soil moisture and expected precipitation.
➢ Exchange Rate: After its surge in January 2022, the value of AFN started to consistently appreciate against the USD during the year 2023 and remains relatively stable, hovering around AFN 70-74 per USD since November 2023. The monthly average exchange rate between AFN and USD was recorded at AFN 71.4 per 1 USD during March 2024 and the weekly average rate in third week of April stands at AFN 72.1 per 1USD.

claims.sentence: [meeting minutes] early warning information working group (ewiwg) presented comprehensive overview early warning information cluster partners.

 content: The Early Warning Information Working Group (EWIWG) presented a comprehensive overview of early warning information to the cluster partners. Here are the key highlights from the presentation.
➢ Precipitation: rainfall for the 2023/24 winter wet season, from October 2023 to March 2024, is most likely to be below average, with areas with average values. Average precipitation is most likely to occur from March to May 2024, during the wet spring season. Spring rains are expected to have normal timing and distribution, with minimal adverse impact on typical agricultural activities through flooding.
➢ Temperature: Above average daily mean temperatures are most likely through September 2024. Extreme temperatures during May-July and July-September (upper quintile) are 2-3 times more likely than climatology. The consequences of the above-average temperature may be moisture stress in rainfed crops and rangelands and reduced water availability, mainly in the downstream areas that may experience extended dry spells.
➢ Snow Water Volumes: Given below-average antecedent precipitation and current snow water volumes, below-average snow water volumes are expected in the coming months. However, there is more snow than in 2023, given recent accumulations due to above-average precipitation in February and March. Above-average temperatures will likely result in an early snow melt through May 2024.
➢ Wheat planting: Farmers are expected to use the spring window to complete the wheat planting process this season. The success of the coming cropping season depends on timely and welldistributed precipitation in the coming months & the availability of irrigation water in the summertime. ➢ Rangeland vegetative conditions during the 2024 spring (March-May) are expected to improve and most likely to be near average in most areas, with some below-average areas due to the persistence of current conditions and above-average temperatures. During summer (JuneSeptember), most areas will turn to below-average, due to below-average cumulative 2023/24 precipitation, above-average temperatures, or both.

Moreover, concerns exist about the risk of locust infestation in crops and pasture areas. ➢ Exchange Rate: After its surge in January 2022, the value of AFN started to consistently appreciate against the USD during the year 2023 and remains relatively stable, hovering around AFN 70-74 per USD since November 2023. The monthly average exchange rate between AFN and USD was recorded at AFN 71.4 per 1 USD during March 2024 and the weekly average rate in third week of April stands at AFN 72.1 per 1USD.

metadata.title: Afghanistan: Minutes of FSAC Monthly Meeting (24 April 2024) [Meeting Minutes]
metadata.content:
title: Afghanistan: Minutes of FSAC Monthly Meeting (24 April 2024) [Meeting Minutes] 
 content: The Early Warning Information Working Group (EWIWG) presented a comprehensive overview of early warning information to the cluster partners. Here are the key highlights from the presentation.
➢ Precipitation: rainfall for the 2023/24 winter wet season, from October 2023 to March 2024, is most likely to be below average, with areas with average values. Average precipitation is most likely to occur from March to May 2024, during the wet spring season. Spring rains are expected to have normal timing and distribution, with minimal adverse impact on typical agricultural activities through flooding.
➢ Temperature: Above average daily mean temperatures are most likely through September 2024. Extreme temperatures during May-July and July-September (upper quintile) are 2-3 times more likely than climatology. The consequences of the above-average temperature may be moisture stress in rainfed crops and rangelands and reduced water availability, mainly in the downstream areas that may experience extended dry spells.
➢ Snow Water Volumes: Given below-average antecedent precipitation and current snow water volumes, below-average snow water volumes are expected in the coming months. However, there is more snow than in 2023, given recent accumulations due to above-average precipitation in February and March. Above-average temperatures will likely result in an early snow melt through May 2024.
➢ Wheat planting: Farmers are expected to use the spring window to complete the wheat planting process this season. The success of the coming cropping season depends on timely and welldistributed precipitation in the coming months & the availability of irrigation water in the summertime. ➢ Rangeland vegetative conditions during the 2024 spring (March-May) are expected to improve and most likely to be near average in most areas, with some below-average areas due to the persistence of current conditions and above-average temperatures. During summer (JuneSeptember), most areas will turn to below-average, due to below-average cumulative 2023/24 precipitation, above-average temperatures, or both.
➢ Possible risks: The combination of average to above-average precipitation and above-average temperatures during the remainder of the 2023/24 agricultural season may elevate the risk of yellow rust affecting the yield and productivity of wheat in the eastern, northern, northeastern, and southern provinces. Moreover, concerns exist about the risk of locust infestation in crops and pasture areas. The anticipated near-average to average cumulative precipitation in 2024 will enhance vegetation conditions, which may facilitate the growth of locust populations in the coming months, particularly in the northern and northeastern provinces.
➢ Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI): A worsen NDVI mainly in northern and eastern and central parts of the country is seen. The land surface Temperature (LST) has reduced significantly in the southern and western. This means that due to the negative LST the vegetation could be impacted.
➢ Soil Moisture: Currently below average and better than last year but expected to improve given soil moisture and expected precipitation.
➢ Exchange Rate: After its surge in January 2022, the value of AFN started to consistently appreciate against the USD during the year 2023 and remains relatively stable, hovering around AFN 70-74 per USD since November 2023. The monthly average exchange rate between AFN and USD was recorded at AFN 71.4 per 1 USD during March 2024 and the weekly average rate in third week of April stands at AFN 72.1 per 1USD.

Are there specific regions or communitie.summary:
Yes, several specific regions and communities require prioritized attention due to significant disparities in infrastructure, services, education, health, economic opportunity, and environmental justice. Rural areas and remote rural settlements are identified as needing infrastructure development, such as roads, bridges, and internet access, as they often lack basic services and face educational disparities like inadequate funding and teacher shortages [1][2]. Similarly, under-resourced urban neighborhoods also require prioritized attention to address educational challenges, including teacher shortages and outdated learning materials [2].

Low-income communities are a key focus for public health interventions due to higher rates of chronic diseases and limited healthcare access, and for environmental justice initiatives as they disproportionately suffer from pollution and climate change impacts [3][5]. Indigenous populations also face significant public health challenges, including limited access to healthcare and environmental hazards [3]. Furthermore, communities of color are highlighted as disproportionately affected by pollution and climate change impacts, necessitating environmental protection and adaptation measures [5]. Within marginalized communities, specific groups such as women, youth, and ethnic minorities require economic empowerment due to barriers in employment, financial services, and entrepreneurship [4].

metadata.title: UNICEF Afghanistan Humanitarian Situation Update No. 2 (Northern Region Flash Floods) for 26 May 2024.
metadata.content:
title: UNICEF Afghanistan Humanitarian Situation Update No. 2 (Northern Region Flash Floods) for 26 May 2024. 
 content: Highlights:
On 10 and 11 May, heavy rainfall and flash floods struck northeastern Afghanistan, affecting 21 districts across Badakhshan (5), Baghlan (10), and Takhar (6) provinces. To date, reports suggest that 347 people are confirmed killed and 1,651 injured1. Approximately 7,800 homes were either destroyed or damaged, leaving over 5,000 families displaced according to the de facto Ministry of Refugees and Repatriation. In addition to damaged or destroyed roads, bridges, health facilities and public schools, agricultural land and livestock were also lost.
Between 16 and 17 May 2024, Ghor province experienced heavy rains and flash floods that affected 10 districts2, with Murghab being the most affected. Reports suggest that 40 people were killed, including 10 children; 20 people are missing and 49 are injured. Preliminary reports indicate that over 410 families’ homes were destroyed or partially damaged, 27 health and nutrition facilities were destroyed or partially damaged, and 62 schools are severely damaged.
On 17 May, Faryab province was also affected by flash flooding impacting 9 districts4. Preliminary reports suggest that 62 people were killed and 18 people were injured. In addition, 1,890 houses were damaged or destroyed, and three health facilities and 23 schools were impacted.

claims.sentence: highlights: 10 11 may, heavy rainfall flash floods struck northeastern afghanistan, affecting 21 districts across badakhshan (5), baghlan (10), takhar (6) provinces.

metadata.title: Afghanistan Floods: Flash Update #3 - Floods hit the Northeastern Region of Afghanistan (22 May 2024)
metadata.content:
title: Afghanistan Floods: Flash Update #3 - Floods hit the Northeastern Region of Afghanistan (22 May 2024) 
 content: Highlights
Humanitarian partners are ramping up response efforts following 10 and 11 May heavy rainfall and flash floods in Baghlan, Badakhshan and Takhar provinces that affected more than 60,000 people.
Across the region to date, approximately 7,800 homes have been confirmed as either destroyed or damaged leaving over 5,000 families displaced according to the Afghan Ministry of Refugee and Repatriation (MoRR). In addition to damage and destruction to roads, bridges, health facilities and public schools, agricultural land and livestock have been lost.
To date, across the three provinces MoRR reported 347 people were killed and 1,651 injured due to floods. These figures are expected to increase in the days ahead as humanitarian responders are actively engaged in ongoing assessments.
Overview
On 10 and 11 May, heavy rainfall led to fast-flowing water and flash floods in northeastern Afghanistan affecting 23 districts across Baghlan (Baghlan e Jedid, Burka, Dahne Ghori, Doshi, Guzargai Noor, Jelga, Khost, Pul Hesar, Pul e Khumri, Nahrin, and Tala wa Barfak), Badakhshan (Argo, Darayem, Kohistan, Nosai, Tagab, Teshkan, Yawan, Warduj) and Takhar (Bangi, Chall, Farkhar, Ishkamesh, Namakab, and Taloqan) provinces. While several roads and thoroughfares, particularly in Guzargah Noor, Khost, and Jelga districts in Baghlan province, resulting in significant physical access issues. According to the MoRR, nearly 14,000 livestock died and about 24,000 hectors of land have been destroyed across the region

claims.sentence: across region date, approximately 7,800 homes confirmed either destroyed damaged leaving 5,000 families displaced according afghan ministry refugee repatriation (morr).

Across the region to date, approximately 7,800 homes have been confirmed as either destroyed or damaged leaving over 5,000 families displaced according to the Afghan Ministry of Refugee and Repatriation (MoRR). In addition to damage and destruction to roads, bridges, health facilities and public schools, agricultural land and livestock have been lost.
To date, across the three provinces MoRR reported 347 people were killed and 1,651 injured due to floods. These figures are expected to increase in the days ahead as humanitarian responders are actively engaged in ongoing assessments.
Overview
On 10 and 11 May, heavy rainfall led to fast-flowing water and flash floods in northeastern Afghanistan affecting 23 districts across Baghlan (Baghlan e Jedid, Burka, Dahne Ghori, Doshi, Guzargai Noor, Jelga, Khost, Pul Hesar, Pul e Khumri, Nahrin, and Tala wa Barfak), Badakhshan (Argo, Darayem, Kohistan, Nosai, Tagab, Teshkan, Yawan, Warduj) and Takhar (Bangi, Chall, Farkhar, Ishkamesh, Namakab, and Taloqan) provinces. While several roads and thoroughfares, particularly in Guzargah Noor, Khost, and Jelga districts in Baghlan province, resulting in significant physical access issues. According to the MoRR, nearly 14,000 livestock died and about 24,000 hectors of land have been destroyed across the region

metadata.title: UNICEF Afghanistan Humanitarian Situation Update No. 1 (Northern Region Flash Floods): 20 May 2024
metadata.content:
title: UNICEF Afghanistan Humanitarian Situation Update No. 1 (Northern Region Flash Floods): 20 May 2024 
 content: Highlights
On 10 and 11 May, heavy rainfall and flash floods struck northeastern Afghanistan, affecting 21 districts across Badakhshan (5), Baghlan (10) and Takhar (6) provinces. To date, reports suggest that 180 people have been confirmed killed and 280 injured . Among the most affected districts are Burka and Baghlani Jadid in Baghlan Province where 80 per cent of deaths have been recorded. Rising water levels continue to be reported in a total of 6 districts of Baghlan province (Baghlani Jadid, Nahrin, Burka, Pul Khumri, Dahan e Ghori Doshi and Guzargah Noor, district). The weekend’s rains have caused the largest flooding event in Afghanistan so far this year. Prior to this flooding episode, 30,055 people (4,095 families) had been affected by floods across the country, mainly in the southern and western regions. Preliminary reports suggest that during the period 16-17 May, over 2,500 families were also affected by flooding in Ghor Province.
UNICEF Emergency Response Teams are on the ground supporting ongoing immediate interventions in the affected areas through water trucking, provision of essential supplies including hygiene kits, family kits, blankets, tarpaulin, and multi-purpose cash. Plans are underway to scale up ongoing health, WASH, education, nutrition, child protection, social behaviour change and emergency cash transfer interventions in the affected areas. UNICEF is also developing a costed response plan primarily focusing on the most flood affected provinces in the northern and western regions.

claims.sentence: date, reports suggest 180 people confirmed killed 280 injured .

metadata.title: UNICEF Afghanistan Humanitarian Situation Update No. 1 (Northern Region Flash Floods): 20 May 2024
metadata.content:
title: UNICEF Afghanistan Humanitarian Situation Update No. 1 (Northern Region Flash Floods): 20 May 2024 
 content: Highlights
On 10 and 11 May, heavy rainfall and flash floods struck northeastern Afghanistan, affecting 21 districts across Badakhshan (5), Baghlan (10) and Takhar (6) provinces. To date, reports suggest that 180 people have been confirmed killed and 280 injured . Among the most affected districts are Burka and Baghlani Jadid in Baghlan Province where 80 per cent of deaths have been recorded. Rising water levels continue to be reported in a total of 6 districts of Baghlan province (Baghlani Jadid, Nahrin, Burka, Pul Khumri, Dahan e Ghori Doshi and Guzargah Noor, district). The weekend’s rains have caused the largest flooding event in Afghanistan so far this year. Prior to this flooding episode, 30,055 people (4,095 families) had been affected by floods across the country, mainly in the southern and western regions. Preliminary reports suggest that during the period 16-17 May, over 2,500 families were also affected by flooding in Ghor Province.
UNICEF Emergency Response Teams are on the ground supporting ongoing immediate interventions in the affected areas through water trucking, provision of essential supplies including hygiene kits, family kits, blankets, tarpaulin, and multi-purpose cash. Plans are underway to scale up ongoing health, WASH, education, nutrition, child protection, social behaviour change and emergency cash transfer interventions in the affected areas. UNICEF is also developing a costed response plan primarily focusing on the most flood affected provinces in the northern and western regions.

How do the impacts of the floods on the.summary:
The floods have caused widespread devastation with broadly similar impacts across Badakhshan, Baghlan, and Takhar provinces, although the precise scale of human casualties and specific affected locations differ [1][2][3][4][5][6]. All three provinces have endured significant loss of life, injuries, and the extensive destruction of homes, leading to the displacement of numerous families [1][2][3][5]. Crucially, agricultural lands have been severely damaged, and infrastructure such as roads and bridges has been destroyed, hindering access to affected communities and disrupting essential services [3][4][5]. This widespread damage has resulted in the loss of livelihoods, livestock, and has heightened the risk of food insecurity and increased poverty across all affected areas [3][5][6].

Specifically, Baghlan province has reported the highest number of human casualties, with over 300 individuals killed or injured in districts including Burka, Guzargah-e-Nur, Nahrin, and Baghlani Jadid, where roads to Guzargah-e-Nur and Nahrin were blocked, and power outages occurred [1][2][3][4]. Badakhshan province also experienced a severe toll, with over 200 people killed or injured, particularly in districts such as Registan, Argo, Raghistan, Shuhada, and Yamgan, where the Faizabad-Baharak-Shuhada road was rendered impassable [1][2][3][4]. Takhar province recorded over 140 casualties in areas including Ishkamish, Kalafgan, Farkhar, Taloqan, and Warsaj, with critical routes like the Takhar-Baghlan highway and roads to Farkhar and Warsaj districts becoming blocked [1][2][3][4]. Despite these variations in specific district impacts and casualty numbers, each province has seen more than 2,000 families affected, underscoring a universal and urgent need for humanitarian aid, including food, shelter, non-food items, and medical assistance, as initial assessments continue [1][2][4][5].

claims.sentence: unicef afghanistan humanitarian situation update no. 2 (northern region flash floods) 26 may 2024.

metadata.title: UNICEF Afghanistan Humanitarian Situation Update No. 2 (Northern Region Flash Floods) for 26 May 2024.
metadata.content:
title: UNICEF Afghanistan Humanitarian Situation Update No. 2 (Northern Region Flash Floods) for 26 May 2024. 
 content: Highlights:
On 10 and 11 May, heavy rainfall and flash floods struck northeastern Afghanistan, affecting 21 districts across Badakhshan (5), Baghlan (10), and Takhar (6) provinces. To date, reports suggest that 347 people are confirmed killed and 1,651 injured1. Approximately 7,800 homes were either destroyed or damaged, leaving over 5,000 families displaced according to the de facto Ministry of Refugees and Repatriation. In addition to damaged or destroyed roads, bridges, health facilities and public schools, agricultural land and livestock were also lost.
Between 16 and 17 May 2024, Ghor province experienced heavy rains and flash floods that affected 10 districts2, with Murghab being the most affected. Reports suggest that 40 people were killed, including 10 children; 20 people are missing and 49 are injured. Preliminary reports indicate that over 410 families’ homes were destroyed or partially damaged, 27 health and nutrition facilities were destroyed or partially damaged, and 62 schools are severely damaged.
On 17 May, Faryab province was also affected by flash flooding impacting 9 districts4. Preliminary reports suggest that 62 people were killed and 18 people were injured. In addition, 1,890 houses were damaged or destroyed, and three health facilities and 23 schools were impacted.

claims.sentence: highlights: 10 11 may, heavy rainfall flash floods struck northeastern afghanistan, affecting 21 districts across badakhshan (5), baghlan (10), takhar (6) provinces.

metadata.title: Afghanistan Floods: Flash Update #3 - Floods hit the Northeastern Region of Afghanistan (22 May 2024)
metadata.content:
title: Afghanistan Floods: Flash Update #3 - Floods hit the Northeastern Region of Afghanistan (22 May 2024) 
 content: Highlights
Humanitarian partners are ramping up response efforts following 10 and 11 May heavy rainfall and flash floods in Baghlan, Badakhshan and Takhar provinces that affected more than 60,000 people.
Across the region to date, approximately 7,800 homes have been confirmed as either destroyed or damaged leaving over 5,000 families displaced according to the Afghan Ministry of Refugee and Repatriation (MoRR). In addition to damage and destruction to roads, bridges, health facilities and public schools, agricultural land and livestock have been lost.
To date, across the three provinces MoRR reported 347 people were killed and 1,651 injured due to floods. These figures are expected to increase in the days ahead as humanitarian responders are actively engaged in ongoing assessments.
Overview
On 10 and 11 May, heavy rainfall led to fast-flowing water and flash floods in northeastern Afghanistan affecting 23 districts across Baghlan (Baghlan e Jedid, Burka, Dahne Ghori, Doshi, Guzargai Noor, Jelga, Khost, Pul Hesar, Pul e Khumri, Nahrin, and Tala wa Barfak), Badakhshan (Argo, Darayem, Kohistan, Nosai, Tagab, Teshkan, Yawan, Warduj) and Takhar (Bangi, Chall, Farkhar, Ishkamesh, Namakab, and Taloqan) provinces. While several roads and thoroughfares, particularly in Guzargah Noor, Khost, and Jelga districts in Baghlan province, resulting in significant physical access issues. According to the MoRR, nearly 14,000 livestock died and about 24,000 hectors of land have been destroyed across the region

claims.sentence: across region date, approximately 7,800 homes confirmed either destroyed damaged leaving 5,000 families displaced according afghan ministry refugee repatriation (morr).

metadata.title: UNICEF Afghanistan Humanitarian Situation Update No. 1 (Northern Region Flash Floods): 20 May 2024
metadata.content:
title: UNICEF Afghanistan Humanitarian Situation Update No. 1 (Northern Region Flash Floods): 20 May 2024 
 content: Highlights
On 10 and 11 May, heavy rainfall and flash floods struck northeastern Afghanistan, affecting 21 districts across Badakhshan (5), Baghlan (10) and Takhar (6) provinces. To date, reports suggest that 180 people have been confirmed killed and 280 injured . Among the most affected districts are Burka and Baghlani Jadid in Baghlan Province where 80 per cent of deaths have been recorded. Rising water levels continue to be reported in a total of 6 districts of Baghlan province (Baghlani Jadid, Nahrin, Burka, Pul Khumri, Dahan e Ghori Doshi and Guzargah Noor, district). The weekend’s rains have caused the largest flooding event in Afghanistan so far this year. Prior to this flooding episode, 30,055 people (4,095 families) had been affected by floods across the country, mainly in the southern and western regions. Preliminary reports suggest that during the period 16-17 May, over 2,500 families were also affected by flooding in Ghor Province.
UNICEF Emergency Response Teams are on the ground supporting ongoing immediate interventions in the affected areas through water trucking, provision of essential supplies including hygiene kits, family kits, blankets, tarpaulin, and multi-purpose cash. Plans are underway to scale up ongoing health, WASH, education, nutrition, child protection, social behaviour change and emergency cash transfer interventions in the affected areas. UNICEF is also developing a costed response plan primarily focusing on the most flood affected provinces in the northern and western regions.

claims.sentence: date, reports suggest 180 people confirmed killed 280 injured .
