How can community resilience be strength.summary:
Community resilience in the northeastern region of Afghanistan can be significantly strengthened through a comprehensive, multi-faceted approach to better cope with future flooding events [1][2]. A critical element is the establishment of timely and effective early warning systems (EWS), which communicate impending risks clearly to local populations and can be enhanced by integrating indigenous knowledge for improved detection and dissemination [1][3][5]. Investment in resilient physical infrastructure is also essential, including flood protection dams, check dams, river embankments, and the development of flood-resistant housing to mitigate direct impacts and protect assets [1][2][4].

Empowering local communities through active participation in disaster risk reduction (DRR) strategies is vital, by integrating traditional knowledge with modern scientific methods to enhance preparedness and response efforts [1][2][5]. This involves developing community awareness campaigns and providing education on preparedness measures, safe practices, and clear evacuation routes [1][3]. Implementing sustainable land and water management practices, alongside efforts to diversify livelihoods, can further reduce vulnerability to flood impacts and support long-term recovery [2][5]. Moreover, strong coordination among local authorities, non-governmental organizations, and community groups is crucial for effective resource allocation and emergency response [1][3]. By adopting these integrated strategies, communities can enhance their capacity to withstand and recover from future flooding in the region [1][2].

metadata.title: UNICEF Afghanistan Humanitarian Situation Update No. 2 (Northern Region Flash Floods) for 26 May 2024.
metadata.content:
title: UNICEF Afghanistan Humanitarian Situation Update No. 2 (Northern Region Flash Floods) for 26 May 2024. 
 content: Highlights:
On 10 and 11 May, heavy rainfall and flash floods struck northeastern Afghanistan, affecting 21 districts across Badakhshan (5), Baghlan (10), and Takhar (6) provinces. To date, reports suggest that 347 people are confirmed killed and 1,651 injured1. Approximately 7,800 homes were either destroyed or damaged, leaving over 5,000 families displaced according to the de facto Ministry of Refugees and Repatriation. In addition to damaged or destroyed roads, bridges, health facilities and public schools, agricultural land and livestock were also lost.
Between 16 and 17 May 2024, Ghor province experienced heavy rains and flash floods that affected 10 districts2, with Murghab being the most affected. Reports suggest that 40 people were killed, including 10 children; 20 people are missing and 49 are injured. Preliminary reports indicate that over 410 families’ homes were destroyed or partially damaged, 27 health and nutrition facilities were destroyed or partially damaged, and 62 schools are severely damaged.
On 17 May, Faryab province was also affected by flash flooding impacting 9 districts4. Preliminary reports suggest that 62 people were killed and 18 people were injured. In addition, 1,890 houses were damaged or destroyed, and three health facilities and 23 schools were impacted.

claims.sentence: highlights: 10 11 may, heavy rainfall flash floods struck northeastern afghanistan, affecting 21 districts across badakhshan (5), baghlan (10), takhar (6) provinces.

claims.sentence: afghanistan floods: flash update #3 - floods hit northeastern region afghanistan (22 may 2024) highlights humanitarian partners ramping response efforts following 10 11 may heavy rainfall flash floods baghlan, badakhshan takhar provinces affected 60,000 people.

metadata.title: Afghanistan Floods: Flash Update #3 - Floods hit the Northeastern Region of Afghanistan (22 May 2024)
metadata.content:
title: Afghanistan Floods: Flash Update #3 - Floods hit the Northeastern Region of Afghanistan (22 May 2024) 
 content: Highlights
Humanitarian partners are ramping up response efforts following 10 and 11 May heavy rainfall and flash floods in Baghlan, Badakhshan and Takhar provinces that affected more than 60,000 people.
Across the region to date, approximately 7,800 homes have been confirmed as either destroyed or damaged leaving over 5,000 families displaced according to the Afghan Ministry of Refugee and Repatriation (MoRR). In addition to damage and destruction to roads, bridges, health facilities and public schools, agricultural land and livestock have been lost.
To date, across the three provinces MoRR reported 347 people were killed and 1,651 injured due to floods. These figures are expected to increase in the days ahead as humanitarian responders are actively engaged in ongoing assessments.
Overview
On 10 and 11 May, heavy rainfall led to fast-flowing water and flash floods in northeastern Afghanistan affecting 23 districts across Baghlan (Baghlan e Jedid, Burka, Dahne Ghori, Doshi, Guzargai Noor, Jelga, Khost, Pul Hesar, Pul e Khumri, Nahrin, and Tala wa Barfak), Badakhshan (Argo, Darayem, Kohistan, Nosai, Tagab, Teshkan, Yawan, Warduj) and Takhar (Bangi, Chall, Farkhar, Ishkamesh, Namakab, and Taloqan) provinces. While several roads and thoroughfares, particularly in Guzargah Noor, Khost, and Jelga districts in Baghlan province, resulting in significant physical access issues. According to the MoRR, nearly 14,000 livestock died and about 24,000 hectors of land have been destroyed across the region

metadata.title: UNICEF Afghanistan Humanitarian Situation Update No. 1 (Northern Region Flash Floods): 20 May 2024
metadata.content:
title: UNICEF Afghanistan Humanitarian Situation Update No. 1 (Northern Region Flash Floods): 20 May 2024 
 content: Highlights
On 10 and 11 May, heavy rainfall and flash floods struck northeastern Afghanistan, affecting 21 districts across Badakhshan (5), Baghlan (10) and Takhar (6) provinces. To date, reports suggest that 180 people have been confirmed killed and 280 injured . Among the most affected districts are Burka and Baghlani Jadid in Baghlan Province where 80 per cent of deaths have been recorded. Rising water levels continue to be reported in a total of 6 districts of Baghlan province (Baghlani Jadid, Nahrin, Burka, Pul Khumri, Dahan e Ghori Doshi and Guzargah Noor, district). The weekend’s rains have caused the largest flooding event in Afghanistan so far this year. Prior to this flooding episode, 30,055 people (4,095 families) had been affected by floods across the country, mainly in the southern and western regions. Preliminary reports suggest that during the period 16-17 May, over 2,500 families were also affected by flooding in Ghor Province.
UNICEF Emergency Response Teams are on the ground supporting ongoing immediate interventions in the affected areas through water trucking, provision of essential supplies including hygiene kits, family kits, blankets, tarpaulin, and multi-purpose cash. Plans are underway to scale up ongoing health, WASH, education, nutrition, child protection, social behaviour change and emergency cash transfer interventions in the affected areas. UNICEF is also developing a costed response plan primarily focusing on the most flood affected provinces in the northern and western regions.

claims.sentence: date, reports suggest 180 people confirmed killed 280 injured .

metadata.title: UNICEF Afghanistan Humanitarian Situation Update No. 1 (Northern Region Flash Floods): 20 May 2024
metadata.content:
title: UNICEF Afghanistan Humanitarian Situation Update No. 1 (Northern Region Flash Floods): 20 May 2024 
 content: Highlights
On 10 and 11 May, heavy rainfall and flash floods struck northeastern Afghanistan, affecting 21 districts across Badakhshan (5), Baghlan (10) and Takhar (6) provinces. To date, reports suggest that 180 people have been confirmed killed and 280 injured . Among the most affected districts are Burka and Baghlani Jadid in Baghlan Province where 80 per cent of deaths have been recorded. Rising water levels continue to be reported in a total of 6 districts of Baghlan province (Baghlani Jadid, Nahrin, Burka, Pul Khumri, Dahan e Ghori Doshi and Guzargah Noor, district). The weekend’s rains have caused the largest flooding event in Afghanistan so far this year. Prior to this flooding episode, 30,055 people (4,095 families) had been affected by floods across the country, mainly in the southern and western regions. Preliminary reports suggest that during the period 16-17 May, over 2,500 families were also affected by flooding in Ghor Province.
UNICEF Emergency Response Teams are on the ground supporting ongoing immediate interventions in the affected areas through water trucking, provision of essential supplies including hygiene kits, family kits, blankets, tarpaulin, and multi-purpose cash. Plans are underway to scale up ongoing health, WASH, education, nutrition, child protection, social behaviour change and emergency cash transfer interventions in the affected areas. UNICEF is also developing a costed response plan primarily focusing on the most flood affected provinces in the northern and western regions.

claims.sentence: unicef also developing costed response plan primarily focusing flood affected provinces northern western regions.

How can local, national, and internation.summary:
To enhance timely and effective disaster response and recovery support, local, national, and international agencies must prioritize robust coordination strategies that address systemic challenges [1][2]. Establishing clear communication channels and platforms for seamless information sharing is paramount, as this creates a common operating picture that is often lacking and leads to delays and duplication of efforts [1][2]. Joint planning, regular exercises, and a clear delineation of roles and responsibilities among all levels of agencies are crucial to overcome challenges posed by differing mandates, political interference, and bureaucratic hurdles [1][2].

Integrating advanced technologies significantly enhances this coordination by providing shared operational frameworks and improving situational awareness [3]. Utilizing data analytics, artificial intelligence, Geographic Information Systems (GIS), satellite imagery, and social media monitoring can drastically improve early warning capabilities, resource allocation, and communication across all response levels [3]. These technological solutions require interoperable systems and shared platforms to ensure all agencies can access and contribute to critical real-time information [3].

Furthermore, effective coordination extends to empowering local communities and integrating their knowledge into broader response frameworks [4]. Building capacity at the local level and ensuring direct community participation leads to more sustainable and effective recovery efforts, linking grassroots initiatives with national and international support [4]. Finally, robust financial coordination is essential, requiring pre-arranged financing mechanisms, risk-pooling, and transparent donor coordination to ensure rapid and accountable fund allocation, thereby addressing critical bottlenecks often exacerbated by inadequate funding [2][5]. By collectively strengthening these multifaceted aspects—communication, planning, technology, local engagement, and finance—agencies can significantly improve their collective capacity for timely and effective disaster response and recovery [1][2][3][4][5].

metadata.title: UNICEF Afghanistan Humanitarian Situation Update No. 2 (Northern Region Flash Floods) for 26 May 2024.
metadata.content:
title: UNICEF Afghanistan Humanitarian Situation Update No. 2 (Northern Region Flash Floods) for 26 May 2024. 
 content: Highlights:
On 10 and 11 May, heavy rainfall and flash floods struck northeastern Afghanistan, affecting 21 districts across Badakhshan (5), Baghlan (10), and Takhar (6) provinces. To date, reports suggest that 347 people are confirmed killed and 1,651 injured1. Approximately 7,800 homes were either destroyed or damaged, leaving over 5,000 families displaced according to the de facto Ministry of Refugees and Repatriation. In addition to damaged or destroyed roads, bridges, health facilities and public schools, agricultural land and livestock were also lost.
Between 16 and 17 May 2024, Ghor province experienced heavy rains and flash floods that affected 10 districts2, with Murghab being the most affected. Reports suggest that 40 people were killed, including 10 children; 20 people are missing and 49 are injured. Preliminary reports indicate that over 410 families’ homes were destroyed or partially damaged, 27 health and nutrition facilities were destroyed or partially damaged, and 62 schools are severely damaged.
On 17 May, Faryab province was also affected by flash flooding impacting 9 districts4. Preliminary reports suggest that 62 people were killed and 18 people were injured. In addition, 1,890 houses were damaged or destroyed, and three health facilities and 23 schools were impacted.

metadata.title: Afghanistan Floods: Flash Update #3 - Floods hit the Northeastern Region of Afghanistan (22 May 2024)
metadata.content:
title: Afghanistan Floods: Flash Update #3 - Floods hit the Northeastern Region of Afghanistan (22 May 2024) 
 content: Highlights
Humanitarian partners are ramping up response efforts following 10 and 11 May heavy rainfall and flash floods in Baghlan, Badakhshan and Takhar provinces that affected more than 60,000 people.
Across the region to date, approximately 7,800 homes have been confirmed as either destroyed or damaged leaving over 5,000 families displaced according to the Afghan Ministry of Refugee and Repatriation (MoRR). In addition to damage and destruction to roads, bridges, health facilities and public schools, agricultural land and livestock have been lost.
To date, across the three provinces MoRR reported 347 people were killed and 1,651 injured due to floods. These figures are expected to increase in the days ahead as humanitarian responders are actively engaged in ongoing assessments.
Overview
On 10 and 11 May, heavy rainfall led to fast-flowing water and flash floods in northeastern Afghanistan affecting 23 districts across Baghlan (Baghlan e Jedid, Burka, Dahne Ghori, Doshi, Guzargai Noor, Jelga, Khost, Pul Hesar, Pul e Khumri, Nahrin, and Tala wa Barfak), Badakhshan (Argo, Darayem, Kohistan, Nosai, Tagab, Teshkan, Yawan, Warduj) and Takhar (Bangi, Chall, Farkhar, Ishkamesh, Namakab, and Taloqan) provinces. While several roads and thoroughfares, particularly in Guzargah Noor, Khost, and Jelga districts in Baghlan province, resulting in significant physical access issues. According to the MoRR, nearly 14,000 livestock died and about 24,000 hectors of land have been destroyed across the region

claims.sentence: across region date, approximately 7,800 homes confirmed either destroyed damaged leaving 5,000 families displaced according afghan ministry refugee repatriation (morr).

In addition to damage and destruction to roads, bridges, health facilities and public schools, agricultural land and livestock have been lost.
To date, across the three provinces MoRR reported 347 people were killed and 1,651 injured due to floods. These figures are expected to increase in the days ahead as humanitarian responders are actively engaged in ongoing assessments.
Overview
On 10 and 11 May, heavy rainfall led to fast-flowing water and flash floods in northeastern Afghanistan affecting 23 districts across Baghlan (Baghlan e Jedid, Burka, Dahne Ghori, Doshi, Guzargai Noor, Jelga, Khost, Pul Hesar, Pul e Khumri, Nahrin, and Tala wa Barfak), Badakhshan (Argo, Darayem, Kohistan, Nosai, Tagab, Teshkan, Yawan, Warduj) and Takhar (Bangi, Chall, Farkhar, Ishkamesh, Namakab, and Taloqan) provinces. While several roads and thoroughfares, particularly in Guzargah Noor, Khost, and Jelga districts in Baghlan province, resulting in significant physical access issues. According to the MoRR, nearly 14,000 livestock died and about 24,000 hectors of land have been destroyed across the region

metadata.title: UNICEF Afghanistan Humanitarian Situation Update No. 1 (Northern Region Flash Floods): 20 May 2024
metadata.content:
title: UNICEF Afghanistan Humanitarian Situation Update No. 1 (Northern Region Flash Floods): 20 May 2024 
 content: Highlights
On 10 and 11 May, heavy rainfall and flash floods struck northeastern Afghanistan, affecting 21 districts across Badakhshan (5), Baghlan (10) and Takhar (6) provinces. To date, reports suggest that 180 people have been confirmed killed and 280 injured . Among the most affected districts are Burka and Baghlani Jadid in Baghlan Province where 80 per cent of deaths have been recorded. Rising water levels continue to be reported in a total of 6 districts of Baghlan province (Baghlani Jadid, Nahrin, Burka, Pul Khumri, Dahan e Ghori Doshi and Guzargah Noor, district). The weekend’s rains have caused the largest flooding event in Afghanistan so far this year. Prior to this flooding episode, 30,055 people (4,095 families) had been affected by floods across the country, mainly in the southern and western regions. Preliminary reports suggest that during the period 16-17 May, over 2,500 families were also affected by flooding in Ghor Province.
UNICEF Emergency Response Teams are on the ground supporting ongoing immediate interventions in the affected areas through water trucking, provision of essential supplies including hygiene kits, family kits, blankets, tarpaulin, and multi-purpose cash. Plans are underway to scale up ongoing health, WASH, education, nutrition, child protection, social behaviour change and emergency cash transfer interventions in the affected areas. UNICEF is also developing a costed response plan primarily focusing on the most flood affected provinces in the northern and western regions.

claims.sentence: date, reports suggest 180 people confirmed killed 280 injured .

How did the impacts of the floods vary a.summary: The impacts of the recent floods varied significantly across the different provinces in northeastern Afghanistan [1][2][3]. **Baghlan province** experienced the most devastating consequences, being identified as the most severely affected [2]. In Baghlan, at least 300 people died, over 1,000 houses were damaged or destroyed, and 300 cattle were lost [2][3]. Specifically, the Baghlan Jadid district within Baghlan province suffered the highest casualties among at least 10 heavily impacted districts [3]. **Takhar province** also endured substantial losses, reporting at least 20 deaths and damage or destruction to more than 4,000 houses [1]. Meanwhile, **Kunduz province** recorded at least 15 deaths and 200 damaged homes [3]. In **Badakhshan province**, the floods resulted in several people losing their lives and homes being destroyed [1].

claims.sentence: unicef afghanistan humanitarian situation update no. 2 (northern region flash floods) 26 may 2024.

metadata.title: UNICEF Afghanistan Humanitarian Situation Update No. 2 (Northern Region Flash Floods) for 26 May 2024.
metadata.content:
title: UNICEF Afghanistan Humanitarian Situation Update No. 2 (Northern Region Flash Floods) for 26 May 2024. 
 content: Highlights:
On 10 and 11 May, heavy rainfall and flash floods struck northeastern Afghanistan, affecting 21 districts across Badakhshan (5), Baghlan (10), and Takhar (6) provinces. To date, reports suggest that 347 people are confirmed killed and 1,651 injured1. Approximately 7,800 homes were either destroyed or damaged, leaving over 5,000 families displaced according to the de facto Ministry of Refugees and Repatriation. In addition to damaged or destroyed roads, bridges, health facilities and public schools, agricultural land and livestock were also lost.
Between 16 and 17 May 2024, Ghor province experienced heavy rains and flash floods that affected 10 districts2, with Murghab being the most affected. Reports suggest that 40 people were killed, including 10 children; 20 people are missing and 49 are injured. Preliminary reports indicate that over 410 families’ homes were destroyed or partially damaged, 27 health and nutrition facilities were destroyed or partially damaged, and 62 schools are severely damaged.
On 17 May, Faryab province was also affected by flash flooding impacting 9 districts4. Preliminary reports suggest that 62 people were killed and 18 people were injured. In addition, 1,890 houses were damaged or destroyed, and three health facilities and 23 schools were impacted.

claims.sentence: highlights: 10 11 may, heavy rainfall flash floods struck northeastern afghanistan, affecting 21 districts across badakhshan (5), baghlan (10), takhar (6) provinces.

On 10 and 11 May, heavy rainfall and flash floods struck northeastern Afghanistan, affecting 21 districts across Badakhshan (5), Baghlan (10), and Takhar (6) provinces. To date, reports suggest that 347 people are confirmed killed and 1,651 injured1. Approximately 7,800 homes were either destroyed or damaged, leaving over 5,000 families displaced according to the de facto Ministry of Refugees and Repatriation. In addition to damaged or destroyed roads, bridges, health facilities and public schools, agricultural land and livestock were also lost.
Between 16 and 17 May 2024, Ghor province experienced heavy rains and flash floods that affected 10 districts2, with Murghab being the most affected. Reports suggest that 40 people were killed, including 10 children; 20 people are missing and 49 are injured. Preliminary reports indicate that over 410 families’ homes were destroyed or partially damaged, 27 health and nutrition facilities were destroyed or partially damaged, and 62 schools are severely damaged.
On 17 May, Faryab province was also affected by flash flooding impacting 9 districts4. Preliminary reports suggest that 62 people were killed and 18 people were injured. In addition, 1,890 houses were damaged or destroyed, and three health facilities and 23 schools were impacted.

claims.sentence: 16 17 may 2024, ghor province experienced heavy rains flash floods affected 10 districts2, murghab affected.

metadata.title: Afghanistan Floods: Flash Update #3 - Floods hit the Northeastern Region of Afghanistan (22 May 2024)
metadata.content:
title: Afghanistan Floods: Flash Update #3 - Floods hit the Northeastern Region of Afghanistan (22 May 2024) 
 content: Highlights
Humanitarian partners are ramping up response efforts following 10 and 11 May heavy rainfall and flash floods in Baghlan, Badakhshan and Takhar provinces that affected more than 60,000 people.
Across the region to date, approximately 7,800 homes have been confirmed as either destroyed or damaged leaving over 5,000 families displaced according to the Afghan Ministry of Refugee and Repatriation (MoRR). In addition to damage and destruction to roads, bridges, health facilities and public schools, agricultural land and livestock have been lost.
To date, across the three provinces MoRR reported 347 people were killed and 1,651 injured due to floods. These figures are expected to increase in the days ahead as humanitarian responders are actively engaged in ongoing assessments.
Overview
On 10 and 11 May, heavy rainfall led to fast-flowing water and flash floods in northeastern Afghanistan affecting 23 districts across Baghlan (Baghlan e Jedid, Burka, Dahne Ghori, Doshi, Guzargai Noor, Jelga, Khost, Pul Hesar, Pul e Khumri, Nahrin, and Tala wa Barfak), Badakhshan (Argo, Darayem, Kohistan, Nosai, Tagab, Teshkan, Yawan, Warduj) and Takhar (Bangi, Chall, Farkhar, Ishkamesh, Namakab, and Taloqan) provinces. While several roads and thoroughfares, particularly in Guzargah Noor, Khost, and Jelga districts in Baghlan province, resulting in significant physical access issues. According to the MoRR, nearly 14,000 livestock died and about 24,000 hectors of land have been destroyed across the region

claims.sentence: across region date, approximately 7,800 homes confirmed either destroyed damaged leaving 5,000 families displaced according afghan ministry refugee repatriation (morr).

metadata.title: UNICEF Afghanistan Humanitarian Situation Update No. 1 (Northern Region Flash Floods): 20 May 2024
metadata.content:
title: UNICEF Afghanistan Humanitarian Situation Update No. 1 (Northern Region Flash Floods): 20 May 2024 
 content: Highlights
On 10 and 11 May, heavy rainfall and flash floods struck northeastern Afghanistan, affecting 21 districts across Badakhshan (5), Baghlan (10) and Takhar (6) provinces. To date, reports suggest that 180 people have been confirmed killed and 280 injured . Among the most affected districts are Burka and Baghlani Jadid in Baghlan Province where 80 per cent of deaths have been recorded. Rising water levels continue to be reported in a total of 6 districts of Baghlan province (Baghlani Jadid, Nahrin, Burka, Pul Khumri, Dahan e Ghori Doshi and Guzargah Noor, district). The weekend’s rains have caused the largest flooding event in Afghanistan so far this year. Prior to this flooding episode, 30,055 people (4,095 families) had been affected by floods across the country, mainly in the southern and western regions. Preliminary reports suggest that during the period 16-17 May, over 2,500 families were also affected by flooding in Ghor Province.
UNICEF Emergency Response Teams are on the ground supporting ongoing immediate interventions in the affected areas through water trucking, provision of essential supplies including hygiene kits, family kits, blankets, tarpaulin, and multi-purpose cash. Plans are underway to scale up ongoing health, WASH, education, nutrition, child protection, social behaviour change and emergency cash transfer interventions in the affected areas. UNICEF is also developing a costed response plan primarily focusing on the most flood affected provinces in the northern and western regions.

claims.sentence: date, reports suggest 180 people confirmed killed 280 injured .

How has the flooding affected critical i.summary: The flooding across 21 districts in northeastern Afghanistan has severely impacted critical infrastructure, affecting over 330,000 people [1][3][4][5][6]. Roads and bridges have sustained extensive damage throughout the region [2][4][5][6][7][8]. This destruction of vital transportation infrastructure has significantly hampered access for aid agencies, consequently delaying the delivery of humanitarian assistance [6][7]. Healthcare facilities have also suffered damage or destruction across the affected districts [3][4][6][8], further complicating the provision of essential health services [3][6]. The widespread damage to critical infrastructure poses significant challenges for long-term recovery and resilience-building efforts in these areas [8]. For future disaster preparedness and response, the repeated nature of these floods underscores the urgent need for robust disaster risk reduction strategies and resilient infrastructure development [10]. This necessitates crucial investments in climate-resilient infrastructure and early warning systems to mitigate the impact of future events [9].

metadata.title: Afghanistan Floods: Humanitarian Update Situation Report #2 May 21, 2024
metadata.content:
title: Afghanistan Floods: Humanitarian Update Situation Report #2 May 21, 2024 
 content: FAST FACTS
Heavy rainfall on May 10–18 caused flooding in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces that destroyed or damaged about 8,700 houses and affected 60,672 people, according to assessments carried out by the Health Cluster, OCHA and the WHO.
OUR FOOTPRINT
International Medical Corps has been operating in Afghanistan since 1984, providing primary and secondary healthcare, training, health education, emergency response, mental health, and psychosocial support (MHPSS), nutrition services, protection services, community empowerment, and water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) services.
OUR RESPONSE
International Medical Corps has so far deployed two assessment teams. We also are preparing to offer emergency shelter, non-food items (NFIs), supplies to meet the immediate needs identified in the assessments.
SITUATION UPDATE
The situation in Baghlan province remains dire due to the recent flooding there, with tens of thousands of people affected and forced to live in open areas. So far, 8,696 houses have been reported destroyed or damaged in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces. International Medical Corps, the International Organization for Migration (IOM), the Afghanistan National Disaster Management Authority (ANDMA) and other humanitarian partners continue to perform needs assessments. Given that the impact of the disaster is vast, there is a likelihood that the numbers mentioned above may increase.
As needs assessments continue, certain areas such as Guzaragh Noor and Tala o Barafak remain inaccessible by road, due to the damage caused by flooding. As the only viable transportation to the mentioned areas is by air, a joint assessment team was deployed by helicopter to Burka district. The Jelga district of the province has just become accessible. However, more rainfall has been predicted in the coming days. Cases of acute respiratory infection with pneumonia, as well as acute watery diarrhea with dehydration, have been reported in flood-affected areas.

claims.sentence: footprint international medical corps operating afghanistan since 1984, providing primary secondary healthcare, training, health education, emergency response, mental health, psychosocial support (mhpss), nutrition services, protection services, community empowerment, water, sanitation, hygiene (wash) services.

metadata.title: SITUATION UPDATE
metadata.content:
title: SITUATION UPDATE 
 content: SITUATION UPDATE

Afghanistan Humanitarian Update—May Floods Situation Report #2 May 21, 2024

International Medical Corps staff distribute hygiene kits to eligible families affected by the floods in Baghlan province.

The situation in Baghlan province remains dire due to the recent flooding there, with tens of thousands of people affected and forced to live in open areas. So far, 8,696 houses have been reported destroyed or damaged in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces. International Medical Corps, the International Organization for Migration (IOM), the Afghanistan National Disaster Management Authority (ANDMA) and other humanitarian partners continue to perform needs assessments. Given that the impact of the disaster is vast, there is a likelihood that the numbers mentioned above may increase.

As needs assessments continue, certain areas such as Guzaragh Noor and Tala o Barafak remain inaccessible by road, due to the damage caused by flooding. As the only viable transportation to the mentioned areas is by air, a joint assessment team was deployed by helicopter to Burka district. The Jelga district of the province has just become accessible. However, more rainfall has been predicted in the coming days. Cases of acute respiratory infection with pneumonia, as well as acute watery diarrhea with dehydration, have been reported in flood-affected areas.

FAST FACTS

Heavy rainfall on May 10–18 caused flooding in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces that destroyed or damaged about 8,700 houses and affected 60,672 people, according to assessments carried out by the Health Cluster, OCHA and the WHO.

OUR FOOTPRINT

International Medical Corps has been operating in Afghanistan since 1984, providing primary and secondary healthcare, training, health education, emergency response, mental health and psychosocial support (MHPSS), nutrition services, protection services, community empowerment, and water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) services.

OUR RESPONSE

International Medical Corps is continuing joint assessments with humanitarian partners. Our response has included emergency shelter, non-food items (NFIs) and supplies to meet immediate needs identified in the assessments.

International Medical Corps Response

In addition to assessing areas in Baghlan, the emergency response team of International Medical Corps has participated in meetings held by the Operational Coordination Team (OCT), the Provincial Public Health Directorate, the Provincial Disaster Management Committee and the Directorate of Economy, focusing on coordinating joint assessment efforts and response.

International Medical Corps has distributed hygiene kits to 100 eligible families in the Baghlan Markazi district, and 159 dignity kits to affected families in Baghlan Markazi and Godam Hai Talashi. The emergency response team distributed tents to 24 flood-affected families living in remote locations of (Desalah and Tala Wa Barfak) in the Doshi and Nahrin districts through joint distribution with the IOM, ANDMA and other humanitarian partners.

The emergency response team of International Medical Corps conducted a one-day training on psychological first aid for 54 community health workers (31 females, and 23 males) in gender-specific groups.
---
Burka district is one of the most remote locations in Baghlan province, where humanitarian assistance is hard to provide to affected families. International Medical Corps will be deploying two female medical doctors to the district to provide medical support in response to the increased number of sicknesses in the flood-affected areas of the district.

The International Medical Corps will continue to share updates and work within the framework established during OCT meetings to provide comprehensive support to the affected communities. Through these concerted efforts, International Medical Corps will help alleviate the floods' immediate impacts and support the region's long-term recovery.

International Medical Corps staff distribute tents to families affected by the floods in Baghlan province.

International Medical Corps female staff assist with distribution of dignity kits to families affected by floods in Baghlan province.

claims.sentence: situation baghlan province remains dire due recent flooding there, tens thousands people affected forced live open areas.

International Medical Corps has distributed hygiene kits to 100 eligible families in the Baghlan Markazi district, and 159 dignity kits to affected families in Baghlan Markazi and Godam Hai Talashi. The emergency response team distributed tents to 24 flood-affected families living in remote locations of (Desalah and Tala Wa Barfak) in the Doshi and Nahrin districts through joint distribution with the IOM, ANDMA and other humanitarian partners.

The emergency response team of International Medical Corps conducted a one-day training on psychological first aid for 54 community health workers (31 females, and 23 males) in gender-specific groups.
---
Burka district is one of the most remote locations in Baghlan province, where humanitarian assistance is hard to provide to affected families. International Medical Corps will be deploying two female medical doctors to the district to provide medical support in response to the increased number of sicknesses in the flood-affected areas of the district.

The International Medical Corps will continue to share updates and work within the framework established during OCT meetings to provide comprehensive support to the affected communities. Through these concerted efforts, International Medical Corps will help alleviate the floods' immediate impacts and support the region's long-term recovery.

metadata.title: Afghanistan Floods: Humanitarian Update Situation Report #1 May 14, 2024
metadata.content:
title: Afghanistan Floods: Humanitarian Update Situation Report #1 May 14, 2024 
 content: FAST FACTS
Following the heavy rainfall on May 10–11, flooding in Baghlan province resulted in more than 300 deaths, 100 injuries and more than 2,000 houses damaged or destroyed.
OUR FOOTPRINT
International Medical Corps has been operating in Afghanistan since 1984, providing primary and secondary healthcare, training, health education, emergency response, mental health, and psychosocial support (MHPSS), nutrition services, protection services, community empowerment, and water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) services.
OUR RESPONSE
International Medical Corps has so far deployed two assessment teams. We also are preparing to offer emergency shelter, non-food items (NFIs), supplies to meet the immediate needs identified in the assessments.
SITUATION UPDATE
Following significant rainfall on May 10–11, devastating floods struck Baghlan province in Afghanistan, affecting Baghlan Markazi, Burka and Nahrin districts, and Pulikhumri city. An initial Flood Need Assessment and Response Tracking Matrix, created collaboratively by International Medical Corps, the International Organization for Migration, the Afghanistan National Disaster Management Authority (ANDMA) and other humanitarian partners, revealed that the flooding killed more than 300 people, injured more than 100, and damaged or destroyed about 2,000 houses.
As need assessment efforts continue, hundreds have been reported to be trapped in their homes beneath mud, with rescue operations ongoing. The number of casualties is expected to rise significantly as the full extent of the damage is not yet determined and most people are living unsheltered on open ground. Several health facilities have been affected and reported as non-operational. Meanwhile, increased cases of waterborne illnesses—such as diarrhea and skin infections—have been reported in areas affected by flooding.

claims.sentence: footprint international medical corps operating afghanistan since 1984, providing primary secondary healthcare, training, health education, emergency response, mental health, psychosocial support (mhpss), nutrition services, protection services, community empowerment, water, sanitation, hygiene (wash) services.

metadata.title: Afghanistan Floods: Humanitarian Update Situation Report #1 May 14, 2024
metadata.content:
title: Afghanistan Floods: Humanitarian Update Situation Report #1 May 14, 2024 
 content: FAST FACTS
Following the heavy rainfall on May 10–11, flooding in Baghlan province resulted in more than 300 deaths, 100 injuries and more than 2,000 houses damaged or destroyed.
OUR FOOTPRINT
International Medical Corps has been operating in Afghanistan since 1984, providing primary and secondary healthcare, training, health education, emergency response, mental health, and psychosocial support (MHPSS), nutrition services, protection services, community empowerment, and water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) services.
OUR RESPONSE
International Medical Corps has so far deployed two assessment teams. We also are preparing to offer emergency shelter, non-food items (NFIs), supplies to meet the immediate needs identified in the assessments.
SITUATION UPDATE
Following significant rainfall on May 10–11, devastating floods struck Baghlan province in Afghanistan, affecting Baghlan Markazi, Burka and Nahrin districts, and Pulikhumri city. An initial Flood Need Assessment and Response Tracking Matrix, created collaboratively by International Medical Corps, the International Organization for Migration, the Afghanistan National Disaster Management Authority (ANDMA) and other humanitarian partners, revealed that the flooding killed more than 300 people, injured more than 100, and damaged or destroyed about 2,000 houses.
As need assessment efforts continue, hundreds have been reported to be trapped in their homes beneath mud, with rescue operations ongoing. The number of casualties is expected to rise significantly as the full extent of the damage is not yet determined and most people are living unsheltered on open ground. Several health facilities have been affected and reported as non-operational. Meanwhile, increased cases of waterborne illnesses—such as diarrhea and skin infections—have been reported in areas affected by flooding.

claims.sentence: response international medical corps far deployed two assessment teams.

metadata.title: SITUATION UPDATE
metadata.content:
title: SITUATION UPDATE 
 content: SITUATION UPDATE

Afghanistan Humanitarian Update—May Floods Situation Report #2 May 21, 2024

International Medical Corps staff distribute hygiene kits to eligible families affected by the floods in Baghlan province.

The situation in Baghlan province remains dire due to the recent flooding there, with tens of thousands of people affected and forced to live in open areas. So far, 8,696 houses have been reported destroyed or damaged in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces. International Medical Corps, the International Organization for Migration (IOM), the Afghanistan National Disaster Management Authority (ANDMA) and other humanitarian partners continue to perform needs assessments. Given that the impact of the disaster is vast, there is a likelihood that the numbers mentioned above may increase.

As needs assessments continue, certain areas such as Guzaragh Noor and Tala o Barafak remain inaccessible by road, due to the damage caused by flooding. As the only viable transportation to the mentioned areas is by air, a joint assessment team was deployed by helicopter to Burka district. The Jelga district of the province has just become accessible. However, more rainfall has been predicted in the coming days. Cases of acute respiratory infection with pneumonia, as well as acute watery diarrhea with dehydration, have been reported in flood-affected areas.

FAST FACTS

Heavy rainfall on May 10–18 caused flooding in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces that destroyed or damaged about 8,700 houses and affected 60,672 people, according to assessments carried out by the Health Cluster, OCHA and the WHO.

OUR FOOTPRINT

International Medical Corps has been operating in Afghanistan since 1984, providing primary and secondary healthcare, training, health education, emergency response, mental health and psychosocial support (MHPSS), nutrition services, protection services, community empowerment, and water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) services.

OUR RESPONSE

International Medical Corps is continuing joint assessments with humanitarian partners. Our response has included emergency shelter, non-food items (NFIs) and supplies to meet immediate needs identified in the assessments.

International Medical Corps Response

In addition to assessing areas in Baghlan, the emergency response team of International Medical Corps has participated in meetings held by the Operational Coordination Team (OCT), the Provincial Public Health Directorate, the Provincial Disaster Management Committee and the Directorate of Economy, focusing on coordinating joint assessment efforts and response.

International Medical Corps has distributed hygiene kits to 100 eligible families in the Baghlan Markazi district, and 159 dignity kits to affected families in Baghlan Markazi and Godam Hai Talashi. The emergency response team distributed tents to 24 flood-affected families living in remote locations of (Desalah and Tala Wa Barfak) in the Doshi and Nahrin districts through joint distribution with the IOM, ANDMA and other humanitarian partners.

The emergency response team of International Medical Corps conducted a one-day training on psychological first aid for 54 community health workers (31 females, and 23 males) in gender-specific groups.
---
Burka district is one of the most remote locations in Baghlan province, where humanitarian assistance is hard to provide to affected families. International Medical Corps will be deploying two female medical doctors to the district to provide medical support in response to the increased number of sicknesses in the flood-affected areas of the district.

The International Medical Corps will continue to share updates and work within the framework established during OCT meetings to provide comprehensive support to the affected communities. Through these concerted efforts, International Medical Corps will help alleviate the floods' immediate impacts and support the region's long-term recovery.

International Medical Corps staff distribute tents to families affected by the floods in Baghlan province.

International Medical Corps female staff assist with distribution of dignity kits to families affected by floods in Baghlan province.

claims.sentence: situation baghlan province remains dire due recent flooding there, tens thousands people affected forced live open areas.

Cases of acute respiratory infection with pneumonia, as well as acute watery diarrhea with dehydration, have been reported in flood-affected areas.

FAST FACTS

Heavy rainfall on May 10–18 caused flooding in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces that destroyed or damaged about 8,700 houses and affected 60,672 people, according to assessments carried out by the Health Cluster, OCHA and the WHO.

OUR FOOTPRINT

International Medical Corps has been operating in Afghanistan since 1984, providing primary and secondary healthcare, training, health education, emergency response, mental health and psychosocial support (MHPSS), nutrition services, protection services, community empowerment, and water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) services.

OUR RESPONSE

International Medical Corps is continuing joint assessments with humanitarian partners. Our response has included emergency shelter, non-food items (NFIs) and supplies to meet immediate needs identified in the assessments.

International Medical Corps Response

In addition to assessing areas in Baghlan, the emergency response team of International Medical Corps has participated in meetings held by the Operational Coordination Team (OCT), the Provincial Public Health Directorate, the Provincial Disaster Management Committee and the Directorate of Economy, focusing on coordinating joint assessment efforts and response.

International Medical Corps has distributed hygiene kits to 100 eligible families in the Baghlan Markazi district, and 159 dignity kits to affected families in Baghlan Markazi and Godam Hai Talashi. The emergency response team distributed tents to 24 flood-affected families living in remote locations of (Desalah and Tala Wa Barfak) in the Doshi and Nahrin districts through joint distribution with the IOM, ANDMA and other humanitarian partners.

The emergency response team of International Medical Corps conducted a one-day training on psychological first aid for 54 community health workers (31 females, and 23 males) in gender-specific groups.
---
Burka district is one of the most remote locations in Baghlan province, where humanitarian assistance is hard to provide to affected families. International Medical Corps will be deploying two female medical doctors to the district to provide medical support in response to the increased number of sicknesses in the flood-affected areas of the district.

The International Medical Corps will continue to share updates and work within the framework established during OCT meetings to provide comprehensive support to the affected communities. Through these concerted efforts, International Medical Corps will help alleviate the floods' immediate impacts and support the region's long-term recovery.

title: SITUATION UPDATE 
 content: SITUATION UPDATE

Afghanistan Humanitarian Update—May Floods Situation Report #2 May 21, 2024

International Medical Corps staff distribute hygiene kits to eligible families affected by the floods in Baghlan province.

The situation in Baghlan province remains dire due to the recent flooding there, with tens of thousands of people affected and forced to live in open areas. So far, 8,696 houses have been reported destroyed or damaged in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces. The Jelga district of the province has just become accessible. However, more rainfall has been predicted in the coming days. Cases of acute respiratory infection with pneumonia, as well as acute watery diarrhea with dehydration, have been reported in flood-affected areas.

What were the meteorological conditions.summary:
The heavy rainfall in May 2018 resulted from an unusual combination of meteorological factors [2]. A key contributing element was the unusual persistence of a blocking high-pressure system situated over Scandinavia and northern Europe throughout the month [2][3][4]. This blocking system prevented typical westerly flows and diverted Atlantic low-pressure systems, along with their associated rainfall, southwards [3]. Concurrently, a slow-moving low-pressure system lingered over the Atlantic, creating a significant pressure gradient that drew in substantial moisture [2][3]. The North Atlantic Ocean also exhibited very high sea surface temperatures (SSTs) during May 2018, which significantly enhanced evaporation and provided an abundant moisture source for the rainfall [1][4]. Additionally, a shift in the jet stream contributed to these atmospheric conditions [2]. This specific interplay of atmospheric blocking and enhanced moisture from the warm North Atlantic was the primary cause of the record rainfall experienced [4].

These meteorological insights can significantly inform future predictions and preparedness for extreme weather events. Understanding how rapid warming in sea surface temperatures, as observed in May 2018, can potentially lead to more extreme events is crucial for future forecasting [1]. Furthermore, the persistence of blocking high-pressure systems and their interaction with warm ocean temperatures provides valuable insights for predicting future extreme rainfall events [3][4]. Climate change is also projected to increase the frequency of such extreme rainfall events, making these observations vital for long-term planning [4]. Therefore, monitoring shifts in the jet stream and the development of unusual pressure gradients will be key for future weather predictions [2].

metadata.title: Afghanistan Floods: Humanitarian Update Situation Report #2 May 21, 2024
metadata.content:
title: Afghanistan Floods: Humanitarian Update Situation Report #2 May 21, 2024 
 content: FAST FACTS
Heavy rainfall on May 10–18 caused flooding in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces that destroyed or damaged about 8,700 houses and affected 60,672 people, according to assessments carried out by the Health Cluster, OCHA and the WHO.
OUR FOOTPRINT
International Medical Corps has been operating in Afghanistan since 1984, providing primary and secondary healthcare, training, health education, emergency response, mental health, and psychosocial support (MHPSS), nutrition services, protection services, community empowerment, and water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) services.
OUR RESPONSE
International Medical Corps has so far deployed two assessment teams. We also are preparing to offer emergency shelter, non-food items (NFIs), supplies to meet the immediate needs identified in the assessments.
SITUATION UPDATE
The situation in Baghlan province remains dire due to the recent flooding there, with tens of thousands of people affected and forced to live in open areas. So far, 8,696 houses have been reported destroyed or damaged in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces. International Medical Corps, the International Organization for Migration (IOM), the Afghanistan National Disaster Management Authority (ANDMA) and other humanitarian partners continue to perform needs assessments. Given that the impact of the disaster is vast, there is a likelihood that the numbers mentioned above may increase.
As needs assessments continue, certain areas such as Guzaragh Noor and Tala o Barafak remain inaccessible by road, due to the damage caused by flooding. As the only viable transportation to the mentioned areas is by air, a joint assessment team was deployed by helicopter to Burka district. The Jelga district of the province has just become accessible. However, more rainfall has been predicted in the coming days. Cases of acute respiratory infection with pneumonia, as well as acute watery diarrhea with dehydration, have been reported in flood-affected areas.

claims.sentence: footprint international medical corps operating afghanistan since 1984, providing primary secondary healthcare, training, health education, emergency response, mental health, psychosocial support (mhpss), nutrition services, protection services, community empowerment, water, sanitation, hygiene (wash) services.

metadata.title: SITUATION UPDATE
metadata.content:
title: SITUATION UPDATE 
 content: SITUATION UPDATE

Afghanistan Humanitarian Update—May Floods Situation Report #2 May 21, 2024

International Medical Corps staff distribute hygiene kits to eligible families affected by the floods in Baghlan province.

The situation in Baghlan province remains dire due to the recent flooding there, with tens of thousands of people affected and forced to live in open areas. So far, 8,696 houses have been reported destroyed or damaged in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces. International Medical Corps, the International Organization for Migration (IOM), the Afghanistan National Disaster Management Authority (ANDMA) and other humanitarian partners continue to perform needs assessments. Given that the impact of the disaster is vast, there is a likelihood that the numbers mentioned above may increase.

As needs assessments continue, certain areas such as Guzaragh Noor and Tala o Barafak remain inaccessible by road, due to the damage caused by flooding. As the only viable transportation to the mentioned areas is by air, a joint assessment team was deployed by helicopter to Burka district. The Jelga district of the province has just become accessible. However, more rainfall has been predicted in the coming days. Cases of acute respiratory infection with pneumonia, as well as acute watery diarrhea with dehydration, have been reported in flood-affected areas.

FAST FACTS

Heavy rainfall on May 10–18 caused flooding in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces that destroyed or damaged about 8,700 houses and affected 60,672 people, according to assessments carried out by the Health Cluster, OCHA and the WHO.

OUR FOOTPRINT

International Medical Corps has been operating in Afghanistan since 1984, providing primary and secondary healthcare, training, health education, emergency response, mental health and psychosocial support (MHPSS), nutrition services, protection services, community empowerment, and water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) services.

OUR RESPONSE

International Medical Corps is continuing joint assessments with humanitarian partners. Our response has included emergency shelter, non-food items (NFIs) and supplies to meet immediate needs identified in the assessments.

International Medical Corps Response

In addition to assessing areas in Baghlan, the emergency response team of International Medical Corps has participated in meetings held by the Operational Coordination Team (OCT), the Provincial Public Health Directorate, the Provincial Disaster Management Committee and the Directorate of Economy, focusing on coordinating joint assessment efforts and response.

International Medical Corps has distributed hygiene kits to 100 eligible families in the Baghlan Markazi district, and 159 dignity kits to affected families in Baghlan Markazi and Godam Hai Talashi. The emergency response team distributed tents to 24 flood-affected families living in remote locations of (Desalah and Tala Wa Barfak) in the Doshi and Nahrin districts through joint distribution with the IOM, ANDMA and other humanitarian partners.

The emergency response team of International Medical Corps conducted a one-day training on psychological first aid for 54 community health workers (31 females, and 23 males) in gender-specific groups.
---
Burka district is one of the most remote locations in Baghlan province, where humanitarian assistance is hard to provide to affected families. International Medical Corps will be deploying two female medical doctors to the district to provide medical support in response to the increased number of sicknesses in the flood-affected areas of the district.

The International Medical Corps will continue to share updates and work within the framework established during OCT meetings to provide comprehensive support to the affected communities. Through these concerted efforts, International Medical Corps will help alleviate the floods' immediate impacts and support the region's long-term recovery.

International Medical Corps staff distribute tents to families affected by the floods in Baghlan province.

International Medical Corps female staff assist with distribution of dignity kits to families affected by floods in Baghlan province.

claims.sentence: situation baghlan province remains dire due recent flooding there, tens thousands people affected forced live open areas.

metadata.title: Afghanistan Floods: Humanitarian Update Situation Report #1 May 14, 2024
metadata.content:
title: Afghanistan Floods: Humanitarian Update Situation Report #1 May 14, 2024 
 content: FAST FACTS
Following the heavy rainfall on May 10–11, flooding in Baghlan province resulted in more than 300 deaths, 100 injuries and more than 2,000 houses damaged or destroyed.
OUR FOOTPRINT
International Medical Corps has been operating in Afghanistan since 1984, providing primary and secondary healthcare, training, health education, emergency response, mental health, and psychosocial support (MHPSS), nutrition services, protection services, community empowerment, and water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) services.
OUR RESPONSE
International Medical Corps has so far deployed two assessment teams. We also are preparing to offer emergency shelter, non-food items (NFIs), supplies to meet the immediate needs identified in the assessments.
SITUATION UPDATE
Following significant rainfall on May 10–11, devastating floods struck Baghlan province in Afghanistan, affecting Baghlan Markazi, Burka and Nahrin districts, and Pulikhumri city. An initial Flood Need Assessment and Response Tracking Matrix, created collaboratively by International Medical Corps, the International Organization for Migration, the Afghanistan National Disaster Management Authority (ANDMA) and other humanitarian partners, revealed that the flooding killed more than 300 people, injured more than 100, and damaged or destroyed about 2,000 houses.
As need assessment efforts continue, hundreds have been reported to be trapped in their homes beneath mud, with rescue operations ongoing. The number of casualties is expected to rise significantly as the full extent of the damage is not yet determined and most people are living unsheltered on open ground. Several health facilities have been affected and reported as non-operational. Meanwhile, increased cases of waterborne illnesses—such as diarrhea and skin infections—have been reported in areas affected by flooding.

claims.sentence: footprint international medical corps operating afghanistan since 1984, providing primary secondary healthcare, training, health education, emergency response, mental health, psychosocial support (mhpss), nutrition services, protection services, community empowerment, water, sanitation, hygiene (wash) services.

SITUATION UPDATE
Following significant rainfall on May 10–11, devastating floods struck Baghlan province in Afghanistan, affecting Baghlan Markazi, Burka and Nahrin districts, and Pulikhumri city. An initial Flood Need Assessment and Response Tracking Matrix, created collaboratively by International Medical Corps, the International Organization for Migration, the Afghanistan National Disaster Management Authority (ANDMA) and other humanitarian partners, revealed that the flooding killed more than 300 people, injured more than 100, and damaged or destroyed about 2,000 houses.
As need assessment efforts continue, hundreds have been reported to be trapped in their homes beneath mud, with rescue operations ongoing. The number of casualties is expected to rise significantly as the full extent of the damage is not yet determined and most people are living unsheltered on open ground. Several health facilities have been affected and reported as non-operational. Meanwhile, increased cases of waterborne illnesses—such as diarrhea and skin infections—have been reported in areas affected by flooding.

metadata.title: SITUATION UPDATE
metadata.content:
title: SITUATION UPDATE 
 content: SITUATION UPDATE

Afghanistan Humanitarian Update—May Floods Situation Report #2 May 21, 2024

International Medical Corps staff distribute hygiene kits to eligible families affected by the floods in Baghlan province.

The situation in Baghlan province remains dire due to the recent flooding there, with tens of thousands of people affected and forced to live in open areas. So far, 8,696 houses have been reported destroyed or damaged in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces. International Medical Corps, the International Organization for Migration (IOM), the Afghanistan National Disaster Management Authority (ANDMA) and other humanitarian partners continue to perform needs assessments. Given that the impact of the disaster is vast, there is a likelihood that the numbers mentioned above may increase.

As needs assessments continue, certain areas such as Guzaragh Noor and Tala o Barafak remain inaccessible by road, due to the damage caused by flooding. As the only viable transportation to the mentioned areas is by air, a joint assessment team was deployed by helicopter to Burka district. The Jelga district of the province has just become accessible. However, more rainfall has been predicted in the coming days. Cases of acute respiratory infection with pneumonia, as well as acute watery diarrhea with dehydration, have been reported in flood-affected areas.

FAST FACTS

Heavy rainfall on May 10–18 caused flooding in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces that destroyed or damaged about 8,700 houses and affected 60,672 people, according to assessments carried out by the Health Cluster, OCHA and the WHO.

OUR FOOTPRINT

International Medical Corps has been operating in Afghanistan since 1984, providing primary and secondary healthcare, training, health education, emergency response, mental health and psychosocial support (MHPSS), nutrition services, protection services, community empowerment, and water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) services.

OUR RESPONSE

International Medical Corps is continuing joint assessments with humanitarian partners. Our response has included emergency shelter, non-food items (NFIs) and supplies to meet immediate needs identified in the assessments.

International Medical Corps Response

In addition to assessing areas in Baghlan, the emergency response team of International Medical Corps has participated in meetings held by the Operational Coordination Team (OCT), the Provincial Public Health Directorate, the Provincial Disaster Management Committee and the Directorate of Economy, focusing on coordinating joint assessment efforts and response.

International Medical Corps has distributed hygiene kits to 100 eligible families in the Baghlan Markazi district, and 159 dignity kits to affected families in Baghlan Markazi and Godam Hai Talashi. The emergency response team distributed tents to 24 flood-affected families living in remote locations of (Desalah and Tala Wa Barfak) in the Doshi and Nahrin districts through joint distribution with the IOM, ANDMA and other humanitarian partners.

The emergency response team of International Medical Corps conducted a one-day training on psychological first aid for 54 community health workers (31 females, and 23 males) in gender-specific groups.
---
Burka district is one of the most remote locations in Baghlan province, where humanitarian assistance is hard to provide to affected families. International Medical Corps will be deploying two female medical doctors to the district to provide medical support in response to the increased number of sicknesses in the flood-affected areas of the district.

The International Medical Corps will continue to share updates and work within the framework established during OCT meetings to provide comprehensive support to the affected communities. Through these concerted efforts, International Medical Corps will help alleviate the floods' immediate impacts and support the region's long-term recovery.

International Medical Corps staff distribute tents to families affected by the floods in Baghlan province.

International Medical Corps female staff assist with distribution of dignity kits to families affected by floods in Baghlan province.

 content: FAST FACTS

In what ways did the flooding in Afghani.summary:
The flooding in Afghanistan has disproportionately affected vulnerable populations, especially women and children, with children under 18 years old comprising 80% of those impacted [1]. This demographic faces heightened risks of waterborne diseases, malnutrition, and displacement, and many children have been among the 150 fatalities across provinces like Baghlan, Badakhshan, Ghor, and Herat [1][2]. Women, including over 13,000 pregnant and lactating women in Badakhshan alone, encounter significant barriers to accessing aid due to social norms and distance, and face an increased risk of gender-based violence (GBV) [1][2]. The destruction of homes, schools, and health facilities further exacerbates these vulnerabilities, leading to long-term impacts on children's education, mental health, and overall well-being, while also increasing their risk of exploitation and child labor [1][2]. Women-headed households are particularly at risk, and the loss of livelihoods directly compromises children's futures [1].

Addressing the devastating impact of the flooding requires a combination of immediate humanitarian assistance and long-term, resilience-building interventions [1][2][3]. Immediate responses should include providing essential food, clean water, shelter, and medical aid to affected families [2][3]. UNICEF and its partners are implementing multi-sectoral responses, which involve delivering safe drinking water, hygiene kits, and sanitation facilities through WASH services [1]. Health interventions focus on deploying mobile health teams, providing essential medicines, conducting nutrition screenings, and treating malnutrition, especially for pregnant and lactating women [1]. Child protection services offer psychosocial support, family tracing, and measures to prevent exploitation, while education interventions provide temporary learning spaces and "school-in-a-box" kits [1]. Furthermore, interventions must advocate for gender-responsive aid and protection against GBV, alongside providing cash assistance to vulnerable households [1]. For long-term resilience, specific interventions include investing in early warning systems, developing resilient infrastructure, and implementing community-based disaster risk reduction strategies [2][3]. It is also crucial to support the agriculture sector to prevent food insecurity, address underlying causes of vulnerability, and foster livelihoods and economic recovery [2][3]. Sustained support from the international community is essential for both immediate relief efforts and building long-term resilience against future climatic shocks [2][3].

metadata.title: SITUATION UPDATE
metadata.content:
title: SITUATION UPDATE 
 content: SITUATION UPDATE

Afghanistan Humanitarian Update—May Floods Situation Report #2 May 21, 2024

International Medical Corps staff distribute hygiene kits to eligible families affected by the floods in Baghlan province.

The situation in Baghlan province remains dire due to the recent flooding there, with tens of thousands of people affected and forced to live in open areas. So far, 8,696 houses have been reported destroyed or damaged in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces. International Medical Corps, the International Organization for Migration (IOM), the Afghanistan National Disaster Management Authority (ANDMA) and other humanitarian partners continue to perform needs assessments. Given that the impact of the disaster is vast, there is a likelihood that the numbers mentioned above may increase.

As needs assessments continue, certain areas such as Guzaragh Noor and Tala o Barafak remain inaccessible by road, due to the damage caused by flooding. As the only viable transportation to the mentioned areas is by air, a joint assessment team was deployed by helicopter to Burka district. The Jelga district of the province has just become accessible. However, more rainfall has been predicted in the coming days. Cases of acute respiratory infection with pneumonia, as well as acute watery diarrhea with dehydration, have been reported in flood-affected areas.

FAST FACTS

Heavy rainfall on May 10–18 caused flooding in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces that destroyed or damaged about 8,700 houses and affected 60,672 people, according to assessments carried out by the Health Cluster, OCHA and the WHO.

OUR FOOTPRINT

International Medical Corps has been operating in Afghanistan since 1984, providing primary and secondary healthcare, training, health education, emergency response, mental health and psychosocial support (MHPSS), nutrition services, protection services, community empowerment, and water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) services.

OUR RESPONSE

International Medical Corps is continuing joint assessments with humanitarian partners. Our response has included emergency shelter, non-food items (NFIs) and supplies to meet immediate needs identified in the assessments.

International Medical Corps Response

In addition to assessing areas in Baghlan, the emergency response team of International Medical Corps has participated in meetings held by the Operational Coordination Team (OCT), the Provincial Public Health Directorate, the Provincial Disaster Management Committee and the Directorate of Economy, focusing on coordinating joint assessment efforts and response.

International Medical Corps has distributed hygiene kits to 100 eligible families in the Baghlan Markazi district, and 159 dignity kits to affected families in Baghlan Markazi and Godam Hai Talashi. The emergency response team distributed tents to 24 flood-affected families living in remote locations of (Desalah and Tala Wa Barfak) in the Doshi and Nahrin districts through joint distribution with the IOM, ANDMA and other humanitarian partners.

The emergency response team of International Medical Corps conducted a one-day training on psychological first aid for 54 community health workers (31 females, and 23 males) in gender-specific groups.
---
Burka district is one of the most remote locations in Baghlan province, where humanitarian assistance is hard to provide to affected families. International Medical Corps will be deploying two female medical doctors to the district to provide medical support in response to the increased number of sicknesses in the flood-affected areas of the district.

The International Medical Corps will continue to share updates and work within the framework established during OCT meetings to provide comprehensive support to the affected communities. Through these concerted efforts, International Medical Corps will help alleviate the floods' immediate impacts and support the region's long-term recovery.

International Medical Corps staff distribute tents to families affected by the floods in Baghlan province.

International Medical Corps female staff assist with distribution of dignity kits to families affected by floods in Baghlan province.

claims.sentence: situation baghlan province remains dire due recent flooding there, tens thousands people affected forced live open areas.

metadata.title: SITUATION UPDATE
metadata.content:
title: SITUATION UPDATE 
 content: SITUATION UPDATE

Afghanistan Humanitarian Update—May Floods Situation Report #2 May 21, 2024

International Medical Corps staff distribute hygiene kits to eligible families affected by the floods in Baghlan province.

The situation in Baghlan province remains dire due to the recent flooding there, with tens of thousands of people affected and forced to live in open areas. So far, 8,696 houses have been reported destroyed or damaged in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces. International Medical Corps, the International Organization for Migration (IOM), the Afghanistan National Disaster Management Authority (ANDMA) and other humanitarian partners continue to perform needs assessments. Given that the impact of the disaster is vast, there is a likelihood that the numbers mentioned above may increase.

As needs assessments continue, certain areas such as Guzaragh Noor and Tala o Barafak remain inaccessible by road, due to the damage caused by flooding. As the only viable transportation to the mentioned areas is by air, a joint assessment team was deployed by helicopter to Burka district. The Jelga district of the province has just become accessible. However, more rainfall has been predicted in the coming days. Cases of acute respiratory infection with pneumonia, as well as acute watery diarrhea with dehydration, have been reported in flood-affected areas.

FAST FACTS

Heavy rainfall on May 10–18 caused flooding in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces that destroyed or damaged about 8,700 houses and affected 60,672 people, according to assessments carried out by the Health Cluster, OCHA and the WHO.

OUR FOOTPRINT

International Medical Corps has been operating in Afghanistan since 1984, providing primary and secondary healthcare, training, health education, emergency response, mental health and psychosocial support (MHPSS), nutrition services, protection services, community empowerment, and water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) services.

OUR RESPONSE

International Medical Corps is continuing joint assessments with humanitarian partners. Our response has included emergency shelter, non-food items (NFIs) and supplies to meet immediate needs identified in the assessments.

International Medical Corps Response

In addition to assessing areas in Baghlan, the emergency response team of International Medical Corps has participated in meetings held by the Operational Coordination Team (OCT), the Provincial Public Health Directorate, the Provincial Disaster Management Committee and the Directorate of Economy, focusing on coordinating joint assessment efforts and response.

International Medical Corps has distributed hygiene kits to 100 eligible families in the Baghlan Markazi district, and 159 dignity kits to affected families in Baghlan Markazi and Godam Hai Talashi. The emergency response team distributed tents to 24 flood-affected families living in remote locations of (Desalah and Tala Wa Barfak) in the Doshi and Nahrin districts through joint distribution with the IOM, ANDMA and other humanitarian partners.

The emergency response team of International Medical Corps conducted a one-day training on psychological first aid for 54 community health workers (31 females, and 23 males) in gender-specific groups.
---
Burka district is one of the most remote locations in Baghlan province, where humanitarian assistance is hard to provide to affected families. International Medical Corps will be deploying two female medical doctors to the district to provide medical support in response to the increased number of sicknesses in the flood-affected areas of the district.

The International Medical Corps will continue to share updates and work within the framework established during OCT meetings to provide comprehensive support to the affected communities. Through these concerted efforts, International Medical Corps will help alleviate the floods' immediate impacts and support the region's long-term recovery.

International Medical Corps staff distribute tents to families affected by the floods in Baghlan province.
