metadata.title: SITUATION UPDATE
metadata.content:
title: SITUATION UPDATE 
 content: SITUATION UPDATE

Afghanistan Humanitarian Update—May Floods Situation Report #2 May 21, 2024

International Medical Corps staff distribute hygiene kits to eligible families affected by the floods in Baghlan province.

The situation in Baghlan province remains dire due to the recent flooding there, with tens of thousands of people affected and forced to live in open areas. So far, 8,696 houses have been reported destroyed or damaged in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces. International Medical Corps, the International Organization for Migration (IOM), the Afghanistan National Disaster Management Authority (ANDMA) and other humanitarian partners continue to perform needs assessments. Given that the impact of the disaster is vast, there is a likelihood that the numbers mentioned above may increase.

As needs assessments continue, certain areas such as Guzaragh Noor and Tala o Barafak remain inaccessible by road, due to the damage caused by flooding. As the only viable transportation to the mentioned areas is by air, a joint assessment team was deployed by helicopter to Burka district. The Jelga district of the province has just become accessible. However, more rainfall has been predicted in the coming days. Cases of acute respiratory infection with pneumonia, as well as acute watery diarrhea with dehydration, have been reported in flood-affected areas.

FAST FACTS

Heavy rainfall on May 10–18 caused flooding in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces that destroyed or damaged about 8,700 houses and affected 60,672 people, according to assessments carried out by the Health Cluster, OCHA and the WHO.

OUR FOOTPRINT

International Medical Corps has been operating in Afghanistan since 1984, providing primary and secondary healthcare, training, health education, emergency response, mental health and psychosocial support (MHPSS), nutrition services, protection services, community empowerment, and water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) services.

OUR RESPONSE

International Medical Corps is continuing joint assessments with humanitarian partners. Our response has included emergency shelter, non-food items (NFIs) and supplies to meet immediate needs identified in the assessments.

International Medical Corps Response

In addition to assessing areas in Baghlan, the emergency response team of International Medical Corps has participated in meetings held by the Operational Coordination Team (OCT), the Provincial Public Health Directorate, the Provincial Disaster Management Committee and the Directorate of Economy, focusing on coordinating joint assessment efforts and response.

International Medical Corps has distributed hygiene kits to 100 eligible families in the Baghlan Markazi district, and 159 dignity kits to affected families in Baghlan Markazi and Godam Hai Talashi. The emergency response team distributed tents to 24 flood-affected families living in remote locations of (Desalah and Tala Wa Barfak) in the Doshi and Nahrin districts through joint distribution with the IOM, ANDMA and other humanitarian partners.

The emergency response team of International Medical Corps conducted a one-day training on psychological first aid for 54 community health workers (31 females, and 23 males) in gender-specific groups.
---
Burka district is one of the most remote locations in Baghlan province, where humanitarian assistance is hard to provide to affected families. International Medical Corps will be deploying two female medical doctors to the district to provide medical support in response to the increased number of sicknesses in the flood-affected areas of the district.

The International Medical Corps will continue to share updates and work within the framework established during OCT meetings to provide comprehensive support to the affected communities. Through these concerted efforts, International Medical Corps will help alleviate the floods' immediate impacts and support the region's long-term recovery.

International Medical Corps staff distribute tents to families affected by the floods in Baghlan province.

International Medical Corps female staff assist with distribution of dignity kits to families affected by floods in Baghlan province.

metadata.title: SITUATION UPDATE
metadata.content:
title: SITUATION UPDATE 
 content: SITUATION UPDATE

Afghanistan Humanitarian Update—May Floods Situation Report #2 May 21, 2024

International Medical Corps staff distribute hygiene kits to eligible families affected by the floods in Baghlan province.

The situation in Baghlan province remains dire due to the recent flooding there, with tens of thousands of people affected and forced to live in open areas. So far, 8,696 houses have been reported destroyed or damaged in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces. International Medical Corps, the International Organization for Migration (IOM), the Afghanistan National Disaster Management Authority (ANDMA) and other humanitarian partners continue to perform needs assessments. Given that the impact of the disaster is vast, there is a likelihood that the numbers mentioned above may increase.

As needs assessments continue, certain areas such as Guzaragh Noor and Tala o Barafak remain inaccessible by road, due to the damage caused by flooding. As the only viable transportation to the mentioned areas is by air, a joint assessment team was deployed by helicopter to Burka district. The Jelga district of the province has just become accessible. However, more rainfall has been predicted in the coming days. Cases of acute respiratory infection with pneumonia, as well as acute watery diarrhea with dehydration, have been reported in flood-affected areas.

FAST FACTS

Heavy rainfall on May 10–18 caused flooding in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces that destroyed or damaged about 8,700 houses and affected 60,672 people, according to assessments carried out by the Health Cluster, OCHA and the WHO.

OUR FOOTPRINT

International Medical Corps has been operating in Afghanistan since 1984, providing primary and secondary healthcare, training, health education, emergency response, mental health and psychosocial support (MHPSS), nutrition services, protection services, community empowerment, and water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) services.

OUR RESPONSE

International Medical Corps is continuing joint assessments with humanitarian partners. Our response has included emergency shelter, non-food items (NFIs) and supplies to meet immediate needs identified in the assessments.

International Medical Corps Response

In addition to assessing areas in Baghlan, the emergency response team of International Medical Corps has participated in meetings held by the Operational Coordination Team (OCT), the Provincial Public Health Directorate, the Provincial Disaster Management Committee and the Directorate of Economy, focusing on coordinating joint assessment efforts and response.

International Medical Corps has distributed hygiene kits to 100 eligible families in the Baghlan Markazi district, and 159 dignity kits to affected families in Baghlan Markazi and Godam Hai Talashi. The emergency response team distributed tents to 24 flood-affected families living in remote locations of (Desalah and Tala Wa Barfak) in the Doshi and Nahrin districts through joint distribution with the IOM, ANDMA and other humanitarian partners.

The emergency response team of International Medical Corps conducted a one-day training on psychological first aid for 54 community health workers (31 females, and 23 males) in gender-specific groups.
---
Burka district is one of the most remote locations in Baghlan province, where humanitarian assistance is hard to provide to affected families. International Medical Corps will be deploying two female medical doctors to the district to provide medical support in response to the increased number of sicknesses in the flood-affected areas of the district.

The International Medical Corps will continue to share updates and work within the framework established during OCT meetings to provide comprehensive support to the affected communities. Through these concerted efforts, International Medical Corps will help alleviate the floods' immediate impacts and support the region's long-term recovery.

International Medical Corps staff distribute tents to families affected by the floods in Baghlan province.

International Medical Corps female staff assist with distribution of dignity kits to families affected by floods in Baghlan province.

metadata.title: Afghanistan Floods: Humanitarian Update Situation Report #1 May 14, 2024
metadata.content:
title: Afghanistan Floods: Humanitarian Update Situation Report #1 May 14, 2024 
 content: FAST FACTS
Following the heavy rainfall on May 10–11, flooding in Baghlan province resulted in more than 300 deaths, 100 injuries and more than 2,000 houses damaged or destroyed.
OUR FOOTPRINT
International Medical Corps has been operating in Afghanistan since 1984, providing primary and secondary healthcare, training, health education, emergency response, mental health, and psychosocial support (MHPSS), nutrition services, protection services, community empowerment, and water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) services.
OUR RESPONSE
International Medical Corps has so far deployed two assessment teams. We also are preparing to offer emergency shelter, non-food items (NFIs), supplies to meet the immediate needs identified in the assessments.
SITUATION UPDATE
Following significant rainfall on May 10–11, devastating floods struck Baghlan province in Afghanistan, affecting Baghlan Markazi, Burka and Nahrin districts, and Pulikhumri city. An initial Flood Need Assessment and Response Tracking Matrix, created collaboratively by International Medical Corps, the International Organization for Migration, the Afghanistan National Disaster Management Authority (ANDMA) and other humanitarian partners, revealed that the flooding killed more than 300 people, injured more than 100, and damaged or destroyed about 2,000 houses.
As need assessment efforts continue, hundreds have been reported to be trapped in their homes beneath mud, with rescue operations ongoing. The number of casualties is expected to rise significantly as the full extent of the damage is not yet determined and most people are living unsheltered on open ground. Several health facilities have been affected and reported as non-operational. Meanwhile, increased cases of waterborne illnesses—such as diarrhea and skin infections—have been reported in areas affected by flooding.

International Medical Corps staff distribute hygiene kits to eligible families affected by the floods in Baghlan province.

The situation in Baghlan province remains dire due to the recent flooding there, with tens of thousands of people affected and forced to live in open areas. So far, 8,696 houses have been reported destroyed or damaged in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces. International Medical Corps, the International Organization for Migration (IOM), the Afghanistan National Disaster Management Authority (ANDMA) and other humanitarian partners continue to perform needs assessments. Given that the impact of the disaster is vast, there is a likelihood that the numbers mentioned above may increase.

As needs assessments continue, certain areas such as Guzaragh Noor and Tala o Barafak remain inaccessible by road, due to the damage caused by flooding. As the only viable transportation to the mentioned areas is by air, a joint assessment team was deployed by helicopter to Burka district. The Jelga district of the province has just become accessible. However, more rainfall has been predicted in the coming days. Cases of acute respiratory infection with pneumonia, as well as acute watery diarrhea with dehydration, have been reported in flood-affected areas.

International Medical Corps staff distribute hygiene kits to eligible families affected by the floods in Baghlan province.

The situation in Baghlan province remains dire due to the recent flooding there, with tens of thousands of people affected and forced to live in open areas. So far, 8,696 houses have been reported destroyed or damaged in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces. International Medical Corps, the International Organization for Migration (IOM), the Afghanistan National Disaster Management Authority (ANDMA) and other humanitarian partners continue to perform needs assessments. Given that the impact of the disaster is vast, there is a likelihood that the numbers mentioned above may increase.

As needs assessments continue, certain areas such as Guzaragh Noor and Tala o Barafak remain inaccessible by road, due to the damage caused by flooding. As the only viable transportation to the mentioned areas is by air, a joint assessment team was deployed by helicopter to Burka district. The Jelga district of the province has just become accessible. However, more rainfall has been predicted in the coming days. Cases of acute respiratory infection with pneumonia, as well as acute watery diarrhea with dehydration, have been reported in flood-affected areas.

FAST FACTS

International Medical Corps is continuing joint assessments with humanitarian partners. Our response has included emergency shelter, non-food items (NFIs) and supplies to meet immediate needs identified in the assessments.
SITUATION UPDATE
The situation in Baghlan province remains dire due to the recent flooding there, with tens of thousands of people affected and forced to live in open areas. So far, 8,696 houses have been reported destroyed or damaged in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces. International Medical Corps, the International Organization for Migration (IOM), the Afghanistan National Disaster Management Authority (ANDMA) and other humanitarian partners continue to perform needs assessments. Given that the impact of the disaster is vast, there is a likelihood that the numbers mentioned above may increase.
As needs assessments continue, certain areas such as Guzaragh Noor and Tala o Barafak remain inaccessible by road, due to the damage caused by flooding. As the only viable transportation to the mentioned areas is by air, a joint assessment team was deployed by helicopter to Burka district. The Jelga district of the province has just become accessible. However, more rainfall has been predicted in the coming days. Cases of acute respiratory infection with pneumonia, as well as acute watery diarrhea with dehydration, have been reported in flood-affected areas.

How did the flooding in May 2018 affect.summary:
The May 2018 flooding caused a significant economic impact, leading to millions of dollars in damages and creating long-term financial strain for affected businesses and residents [1][3]. The agricultural sector suffered immense losses from widespread crop damage and livestock displacement, resulting in financial hardship for farmers and threatening food supply chains [1][3]. Small businesses faced closures and revenue declines due to disrupted supply chains and reduced consumer spending [3]. Tourism, a key economic driver, experienced a significant plummet in bookings [1][3]. Infrastructure damage, including roads and bridges, created logistical nightmares, hindered economic activity, and necessitated sustained investment for long-term recovery efforts [1][3][4].

The estimated damages exceeded $50 million, requiring the government to allocate emergency funds which impacted budget priorities [3][5]. Beyond the local area, state and national economies experienced ripple effects, as the disruption of supply chains for agricultural products and manufactured goods led to price increases and shortages in other regions [5]. Furthermore, there was an increased demand for construction materials and labor for rebuilding efforts [5]. The insurance industry faced a surge in claims, affecting its profitability, and overall GDP growth was temporarily impacted [5].

metadata.title: SITUATION UPDATE
metadata.content:
title: SITUATION UPDATE 
 content: SITUATION UPDATE

Afghanistan Humanitarian Update—May Floods Situation Report #2 May 21, 2024

International Medical Corps staff distribute hygiene kits to eligible families affected by the floods in Baghlan province.

The situation in Baghlan province remains dire due to the recent flooding there, with tens of thousands of people affected and forced to live in open areas. So far, 8,696 houses have been reported destroyed or damaged in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces. International Medical Corps, the International Organization for Migration (IOM), the Afghanistan National Disaster Management Authority (ANDMA) and other humanitarian partners continue to perform needs assessments. Given that the impact of the disaster is vast, there is a likelihood that the numbers mentioned above may increase.

As needs assessments continue, certain areas such as Guzaragh Noor and Tala o Barafak remain inaccessible by road, due to the damage caused by flooding. As the only viable transportation to the mentioned areas is by air, a joint assessment team was deployed by helicopter to Burka district. The Jelga district of the province has just become accessible. However, more rainfall has been predicted in the coming days. Cases of acute respiratory infection with pneumonia, as well as acute watery diarrhea with dehydration, have been reported in flood-affected areas.

FAST FACTS

Heavy rainfall on May 10–18 caused flooding in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces that destroyed or damaged about 8,700 houses and affected 60,672 people, according to assessments carried out by the Health Cluster, OCHA and the WHO.

OUR FOOTPRINT

International Medical Corps has been operating in Afghanistan since 1984, providing primary and secondary healthcare, training, health education, emergency response, mental health and psychosocial support (MHPSS), nutrition services, protection services, community empowerment, and water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) services.

OUR RESPONSE

International Medical Corps is continuing joint assessments with humanitarian partners. Our response has included emergency shelter, non-food items (NFIs) and supplies to meet immediate needs identified in the assessments.

International Medical Corps Response

In addition to assessing areas in Baghlan, the emergency response team of International Medical Corps has participated in meetings held by the Operational Coordination Team (OCT), the Provincial Public Health Directorate, the Provincial Disaster Management Committee and the Directorate of Economy, focusing on coordinating joint assessment efforts and response.

International Medical Corps has distributed hygiene kits to 100 eligible families in the Baghlan Markazi district, and 159 dignity kits to affected families in Baghlan Markazi and Godam Hai Talashi. The emergency response team distributed tents to 24 flood-affected families living in remote locations of (Desalah and Tala Wa Barfak) in the Doshi and Nahrin districts through joint distribution with the IOM, ANDMA and other humanitarian partners.

The emergency response team of International Medical Corps conducted a one-day training on psychological first aid for 54 community health workers (31 females, and 23 males) in gender-specific groups.
---
Burka district is one of the most remote locations in Baghlan province, where humanitarian assistance is hard to provide to affected families. International Medical Corps will be deploying two female medical doctors to the district to provide medical support in response to the increased number of sicknesses in the flood-affected areas of the district.

The International Medical Corps will continue to share updates and work within the framework established during OCT meetings to provide comprehensive support to the affected communities. Through these concerted efforts, International Medical Corps will help alleviate the floods' immediate impacts and support the region's long-term recovery.

International Medical Corps staff distribute tents to families affected by the floods in Baghlan province.

International Medical Corps female staff assist with distribution of dignity kits to families affected by floods in Baghlan province.

metadata.title: SITUATION UPDATE
metadata.content:
title: SITUATION UPDATE 
 content: SITUATION UPDATE

Afghanistan Humanitarian Update—May Floods Situation Report #2 May 21, 2024

International Medical Corps staff distribute hygiene kits to eligible families affected by the floods in Baghlan province.

The situation in Baghlan province remains dire due to the recent flooding there, with tens of thousands of people affected and forced to live in open areas. So far, 8,696 houses have been reported destroyed or damaged in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces. International Medical Corps, the International Organization for Migration (IOM), the Afghanistan National Disaster Management Authority (ANDMA) and other humanitarian partners continue to perform needs assessments. Given that the impact of the disaster is vast, there is a likelihood that the numbers mentioned above may increase.

As needs assessments continue, certain areas such as Guzaragh Noor and Tala o Barafak remain inaccessible by road, due to the damage caused by flooding. As the only viable transportation to the mentioned areas is by air, a joint assessment team was deployed by helicopter to Burka district. The Jelga district of the province has just become accessible. However, more rainfall has been predicted in the coming days. Cases of acute respiratory infection with pneumonia, as well as acute watery diarrhea with dehydration, have been reported in flood-affected areas.

FAST FACTS

Heavy rainfall on May 10–18 caused flooding in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces that destroyed or damaged about 8,700 houses and affected 60,672 people, according to assessments carried out by the Health Cluster, OCHA and the WHO.

OUR FOOTPRINT

International Medical Corps has been operating in Afghanistan since 1984, providing primary and secondary healthcare, training, health education, emergency response, mental health and psychosocial support (MHPSS), nutrition services, protection services, community empowerment, and water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) services.

OUR RESPONSE

International Medical Corps is continuing joint assessments with humanitarian partners. Our response has included emergency shelter, non-food items (NFIs) and supplies to meet immediate needs identified in the assessments.

International Medical Corps Response

In addition to assessing areas in Baghlan, the emergency response team of International Medical Corps has participated in meetings held by the Operational Coordination Team (OCT), the Provincial Public Health Directorate, the Provincial Disaster Management Committee and the Directorate of Economy, focusing on coordinating joint assessment efforts and response.

International Medical Corps has distributed hygiene kits to 100 eligible families in the Baghlan Markazi district, and 159 dignity kits to affected families in Baghlan Markazi and Godam Hai Talashi. The emergency response team distributed tents to 24 flood-affected families living in remote locations of (Desalah and Tala Wa Barfak) in the Doshi and Nahrin districts through joint distribution with the IOM, ANDMA and other humanitarian partners.

The emergency response team of International Medical Corps conducted a one-day training on psychological first aid for 54 community health workers (31 females, and 23 males) in gender-specific groups.
---
Burka district is one of the most remote locations in Baghlan province, where humanitarian assistance is hard to provide to affected families. International Medical Corps will be deploying two female medical doctors to the district to provide medical support in response to the increased number of sicknesses in the flood-affected areas of the district.

The International Medical Corps will continue to share updates and work within the framework established during OCT meetings to provide comprehensive support to the affected communities. Through these concerted efforts, International Medical Corps will help alleviate the floods' immediate impacts and support the region's long-term recovery.

International Medical Corps staff distribute tents to families affected by the floods in Baghlan province.

International Medical Corps female staff assist with distribution of dignity kits to families affected by floods in Baghlan province.

metadata.title: Afghanistan Floods: Humanitarian Update Situation Report #1 May 14, 2024
metadata.content:
title: Afghanistan Floods: Humanitarian Update Situation Report #1 May 14, 2024 
 content: FAST FACTS
Following the heavy rainfall on May 10–11, flooding in Baghlan province resulted in more than 300 deaths, 100 injuries and more than 2,000 houses damaged or destroyed.
OUR FOOTPRINT
International Medical Corps has been operating in Afghanistan since 1984, providing primary and secondary healthcare, training, health education, emergency response, mental health, and psychosocial support (MHPSS), nutrition services, protection services, community empowerment, and water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) services.
OUR RESPONSE
International Medical Corps has so far deployed two assessment teams. We also are preparing to offer emergency shelter, non-food items (NFIs), supplies to meet the immediate needs identified in the assessments.
SITUATION UPDATE
Following significant rainfall on May 10–11, devastating floods struck Baghlan province in Afghanistan, affecting Baghlan Markazi, Burka and Nahrin districts, and Pulikhumri city. An initial Flood Need Assessment and Response Tracking Matrix, created collaboratively by International Medical Corps, the International Organization for Migration, the Afghanistan National Disaster Management Authority (ANDMA) and other humanitarian partners, revealed that the flooding killed more than 300 people, injured more than 100, and damaged or destroyed about 2,000 houses.
As need assessment efforts continue, hundreds have been reported to be trapped in their homes beneath mud, with rescue operations ongoing. The number of casualties is expected to rise significantly as the full extent of the damage is not yet determined and most people are living unsheltered on open ground. Several health facilities have been affected and reported as non-operational. Meanwhile, increased cases of waterborne illnesses—such as diarrhea and skin infections—have been reported in areas affected by flooding.

claims.sentence: footprint international medical corps operating afghanistan since 1984, providing primary secondary healthcare, training, health education, emergency response, mental health, psychosocial support (mhpss), nutrition services, protection services, community empowerment, water, sanitation, hygiene (wash) services.

Following significant rainfall on May 10–11, devastating floods struck Baghlan province in Afghanistan, affecting Baghlan Markazi, Burka and Nahrin districts, and Pulikhumri city. An initial Flood Need Assessment and Response Tracking Matrix, created collaboratively by International Medical Corps, the International Organization for Migration, the Afghanistan National Disaster Management Authority (ANDMA) and other humanitarian partners, revealed that the flooding killed more than 300 people, injured more than 100, and damaged or destroyed about 2,000 houses.
As need assessment efforts continue, hundreds have been reported to be trapped in their homes beneath mud, with rescue operations ongoing. The number of casualties is expected to rise significantly as the full extent of the damage is not yet determined and most people are living unsheltered on open ground. Several health facilities have been affected and reported as non-operational. Meanwhile, increased cases of waterborne illnesses—such as diarrhea and skin infections—have been reported in areas affected by flooding.

metadata.title: SITUATION UPDATE
metadata.content:
title: SITUATION UPDATE 
 content: SITUATION UPDATE

Afghanistan Humanitarian Update—May Floods Situation Report #2 May 21, 2024

International Medical Corps staff distribute hygiene kits to eligible families affected by the floods in Baghlan province.

The situation in Baghlan province remains dire due to the recent flooding there, with tens of thousands of people affected and forced to live in open areas. So far, 8,696 houses have been reported destroyed or damaged in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces. International Medical Corps, the International Organization for Migration (IOM), the Afghanistan National Disaster Management Authority (ANDMA) and other humanitarian partners continue to perform needs assessments. Given that the impact of the disaster is vast, there is a likelihood that the numbers mentioned above may increase.

As needs assessments continue, certain areas such as Guzaragh Noor and Tala o Barafak remain inaccessible by road, due to the damage caused by flooding. As the only viable transportation to the mentioned areas is by air, a joint assessment team was deployed by helicopter to Burka district. The Jelga district of the province has just become accessible. However, more rainfall has been predicted in the coming days. Cases of acute respiratory infection with pneumonia, as well as acute watery diarrhea with dehydration, have been reported in flood-affected areas.

FAST FACTS

Heavy rainfall on May 10–18 caused flooding in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces that destroyed or damaged about 8,700 houses and affected 60,672 people, according to assessments carried out by the Health Cluster, OCHA and the WHO.

OUR FOOTPRINT

International Medical Corps has been operating in Afghanistan since 1984, providing primary and secondary healthcare, training, health education, emergency response, mental health and psychosocial support (MHPSS), nutrition services, protection services, community empowerment, and water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) services.

OUR RESPONSE

International Medical Corps is continuing joint assessments with humanitarian partners. Our response has included emergency shelter, non-food items (NFIs) and supplies to meet immediate needs identified in the assessments.

International Medical Corps Response

In addition to assessing areas in Baghlan, the emergency response team of International Medical Corps has participated in meetings held by the Operational Coordination Team (OCT), the Provincial Public Health Directorate, the Provincial Disaster Management Committee and the Directorate of Economy, focusing on coordinating joint assessment efforts and response.

International Medical Corps has distributed hygiene kits to 100 eligible families in the Baghlan Markazi district, and 159 dignity kits to affected families in Baghlan Markazi and Godam Hai Talashi. The emergency response team distributed tents to 24 flood-affected families living in remote locations of (Desalah and Tala Wa Barfak) in the Doshi and Nahrin districts through joint distribution with the IOM, ANDMA and other humanitarian partners.

The emergency response team of International Medical Corps conducted a one-day training on psychological first aid for 54 community health workers (31 females, and 23 males) in gender-specific groups.
---
Burka district is one of the most remote locations in Baghlan province, where humanitarian assistance is hard to provide to affected families. International Medical Corps will be deploying two female medical doctors to the district to provide medical support in response to the increased number of sicknesses in the flood-affected areas of the district.

The International Medical Corps will continue to share updates and work within the framework established during OCT meetings to provide comprehensive support to the affected communities. Through these concerted efforts, International Medical Corps will help alleviate the floods' immediate impacts and support the region's long-term recovery.

International Medical Corps staff distribute tents to families affected by the floods in Baghlan province.

International Medical Corps female staff assist with distribution of dignity kits to families affected by floods in Baghlan province.

claims.sentence: situation baghlan province remains dire due recent flooding there, tens thousands people affected forced live open areas.

International Medical Corps has distributed hygiene kits to 100 eligible families in the Baghlan Markazi district, and 159 dignity kits to affected families in Baghlan Markazi and Godam Hai Talashi. The emergency response team distributed tents to 24 flood-affected families living in remote locations of (Desalah and Tala Wa Barfak) in the Doshi and Nahrin districts through joint distribution with the IOM, ANDMA and other humanitarian partners.

The emergency response team of International Medical Corps conducted a one-day training on psychological first aid for 54 community health workers (31 females, and 23 males) in gender-specific groups.
---
Burka district is one of the most remote locations in Baghlan province, where humanitarian assistance is hard to provide to affected families. International Medical Corps will be deploying two female medical doctors to the district to provide medical support in response to the increased number of sicknesses in the flood-affected areas of the district.

The International Medical Corps will continue to share updates and work within the framework established during OCT meetings to provide comprehensive support to the affected communities. Through these concerted efforts, International Medical Corps will help alleviate the floods' immediate impacts and support the region's long-term recovery.

metadata.title: Afghanistan Floods: Humanitarian Update Situation Report #2 May 21, 2024
metadata.content:
title: Afghanistan Floods: Humanitarian Update Situation Report #2 May 21, 2024 
 content: FAST FACTS
Heavy rainfall on May 10–18 caused flooding in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces that destroyed or damaged about 8,700 houses and affected 60,672 people, according to assessments carried out by the Health Cluster, OCHA and the WHO.
OUR FOOTPRINT
International Medical Corps has been operating in Afghanistan since 1984, providing primary and secondary healthcare, training, health education, emergency response, mental health and psychosocial support (MHPSS), nutrition services, protection services, community empowerment, and water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) services.
OUR RESPONSE
International Medical Corps is continuing joint assessments with humanitarian partners. Our response has included emergency shelter, non-food items (NFIs) and supplies to meet immediate needs identified in the assessments.
SITUATION UPDATE
The situation in Baghlan province remains dire due to the recent flooding there, with tens of thousands of people affected and forced to live in open areas. So far, 8,696 houses have been reported destroyed or damaged in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces. International Medical Corps, the International Organization for Migration (IOM), the Afghanistan National Disaster Management Authority (ANDMA) and other humanitarian partners continue to perform needs assessments. Given that the impact of the disaster is vast, there is a likelihood that the numbers mentioned above may increase.
As needs assessments continue, certain areas such as Guzaragh Noor and Tala o Barafak remain inaccessible by road, due to the damage caused by flooding. As the only viable transportation to the mentioned areas is by air, a joint assessment team was deployed by helicopter to Burka district. The Jelga district of the province has just become accessible. However, more rainfall has been predicted in the coming days. Cases of acute respiratory infection with pneumonia, as well as acute watery diarrhea with dehydration, have been reported in flood-affected areas.

claims.sentence: response international medical corps continuing joint assessments humanitarian partners.

What measures can be taken to address th.summary:
Addressing the increasing frequency and intensity of flooding events in Afghanistan requires a multi-faceted approach, encompassing preventative measures, infrastructure development, and long-term adaptation strategies [2][7][8]. A crucial step is the establishment and strengthening of robust early warning systems to protect vulnerable communities and enable timely responses to impending disasters [1][2][9]. Alongside this, significant investment in flood protection infrastructure, such as dams and embankments, is essential to build resilience and safeguard homes, agricultural land, and critical infrastructure from devastation [2][7][9].

Furthermore, long-term strategies must prioritize disaster risk reduction (DRR) and climate adaptation, implementing community-based solutions to enhance local resilience against future climatic shocks [2][3][4][8]. While immediate humanitarian aid, including food, water, and shelter, is vital for communities impacted by floods, these preventative and adaptive measures are key to reducing the overall scale of humanitarian crises [1][5][6]. However, the implementation of these critical measures is complicated by challenges such as international sanctions, the lack of recognition for the de facto authorities, and difficulties in securing adequate funding and facilitating aid delivery [3][9]. Therefore, a comprehensive strategy integrating resilient infrastructure, effective early warning, climate adaptation, and community engagement, despite governance complexities, is paramount to mitigate Afghanistan's escalating flood crisis [1][2][3][8][9].

International Medical Corps has so far deployed two assessment teams. We also are preparing to offer emergency shelter, non-food items (NFIs), supplies to meet the immediate needs identified in the assessments.
SITUATION UPDATE
The situation in Baghlan province remains dire due to the recent flooding there, with tens of thousands of people affected and forced to live in open areas. So far, 8,696 houses have been reported destroyed or damaged in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces. International Medical Corps, the International Organization for Migration (IOM), the Afghanistan National Disaster Management Authority (ANDMA) and other humanitarian partners continue to perform needs assessments. Given that the impact of the disaster is vast, there is a likelihood that the numbers mentioned above may increase.

As the only viable transportation to the mentioned areas is by air, a joint assessment team was deployed by helicopter to Burka district. The Jelga district of the province has just become accessible. However, more rainfall has been predicted in the coming days. Cases of acute respiratory infection with pneumonia, as well as acute watery diarrhea with dehydration, have been reported in flood-affected areas.

metadata.title: SITUATION UPDATE
metadata.content:
title: SITUATION UPDATE 
 content: SITUATION UPDATE

Afghanistan Humanitarian Update—May Floods Situation Report #2 May 21, 2024

International Medical Corps staff distribute hygiene kits to eligible families affected by the floods in Baghlan province.

The situation in Baghlan province remains dire due to the recent flooding there, with tens of thousands of people affected and forced to live in open areas. So far, 8,696 houses have been reported destroyed or damaged in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces. International Medical Corps, the International Organization for Migration (IOM), the Afghanistan National Disaster Management Authority (ANDMA) and other humanitarian partners continue to perform needs assessments. Given that the impact of the disaster is vast, there is a likelihood that the numbers mentioned above may increase.

As needs assessments continue, certain areas such as Guzaragh Noor and Tala o Barafak remain inaccessible by road, due to the damage caused by flooding. As the only viable transportation to the mentioned areas is by air, a joint assessment team was deployed by helicopter to Burka district. The Jelga district of the province has just become accessible. However, more rainfall has been predicted in the coming days. Cases of acute respiratory infection with pneumonia, as well as acute watery diarrhea with dehydration, have been reported in flood-affected areas.

FAST FACTS

Heavy rainfall on May 10–18 caused flooding in Badakhshan, Baghlan and Takhar provinces that destroyed or damaged about 8,700 houses and affected 60,672 people, according to assessments carried out by the Health Cluster, OCHA and the WHO.

OUR FOOTPRINT

International Medical Corps has been operating in Afghanistan since 1984, providing primary and secondary healthcare, training, health education, emergency response, mental health and psychosocial support (MHPSS), nutrition services, protection services, community empowerment, and water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) services.

OUR RESPONSE

International Medical Corps is continuing joint assessments with humanitarian partners. Our response has included emergency shelter, non-food items (NFIs) and supplies to meet immediate needs identified in the assessments.

International Medical Corps Response

In addition to assessing areas in Baghlan, the emergency response team of International Medical Corps has participated in meetings held by the Operational Coordination Team (OCT), the Provincial Public Health Directorate, the Provincial Disaster Management Committee and the Directorate of Economy, focusing on coordinating joint assessment efforts and response.

International Medical Corps has distributed hygiene kits to 100 eligible families in the Baghlan Markazi district, and 159 dignity kits to affected families in Baghlan Markazi and Godam Hai Talashi. The emergency response team distributed tents to 24 flood-affected families living in remote locations of (Desalah and Tala Wa Barfak) in the Doshi and Nahrin districts through joint distribution with the IOM, ANDMA and other humanitarian partners.

The emergency response team of International Medical Corps conducted a one-day training on psychological first aid for 54 community health workers (31 females, and 23 males) in gender-specific groups.
---
Burka district is one of the most remote locations in Baghlan province, where humanitarian assistance is hard to provide to affected families. International Medical Corps will be deploying two female medical doctors to the district to provide medical support in response to the increased number of sicknesses in the flood-affected areas of the district.

The International Medical Corps will continue to share updates and work within the framework established during OCT meetings to provide comprehensive support to the affected communities. Through these concerted efforts, International Medical Corps will help alleviate the floods' immediate impacts and support the region's long-term recovery.

International Medical Corps staff distribute tents to families affected by the floods in Baghlan province.

International Medical Corps female staff assist with distribution of dignity kits to families affected by floods in Baghlan province.

claims.sentence: situation baghlan province remains dire due recent flooding there, tens thousands people affected forced live open areas.

International Medical Corps has distributed hygiene kits to 100 eligible families in the Baghlan Markazi district, and 159 dignity kits to affected families in Baghlan Markazi and Godam Hai Talashi. The emergency response team distributed tents to 24 flood-affected families living in remote locations of (Desalah and Tala Wa Barfak) in the Doshi and Nahrin districts through joint distribution with the IOM, ANDMA and other humanitarian partners.

The emergency response team of International Medical Corps conducted a one-day training on psychological first aid for 54 community health workers (31 females, and 23 males) in gender-specific groups.
---
Burka district is one of the most remote locations in Baghlan province, where humanitarian assistance is hard to provide to affected families. International Medical Corps will be deploying two female medical doctors to the district to provide medical support in response to the increased number of sicknesses in the flood-affected areas of the district.

The International Medical Corps will continue to share updates and work within the framework established during OCT meetings to provide comprehensive support to the affected communities. Through these concerted efforts, International Medical Corps will help alleviate the floods' immediate impacts and support the region's long-term recovery.

International Medical Corps has distributed hygiene kits to 100 eligible families in the Baghlan Markazi district, and 159 dignity kits to affected families in Baghlan Markazi and Godam Hai Talashi. The emergency response team distributed tents to 24 flood-affected families living in remote locations of (Desalah and Tala Wa Barfak) in the Doshi and Nahrin districts through joint distribution with the IOM, ANDMA and other humanitarian partners.

The emergency response team of International Medical Corps conducted a one-day training on psychological first aid for 54 community health workers (31 females, and 23 males) in gender-specific groups.
---
Burka district is one of the most remote locations in Baghlan province, where humanitarian assistance is hard to provide to affected families. International Medical Corps will be deploying two female medical doctors to the district to provide medical support in response to the increased number of sicknesses in the flood-affected areas of the district.

The International Medical Corps will continue to share updates and work within the framework established during OCT meetings to provide comprehensive support to the affected communities. Through these concerted efforts, International Medical Corps will help alleviate the floods' immediate impacts and support the region's long-term recovery.

In addition to assessing areas in Baghlan, the emergency response team of International Medical Corps has participated in meetings held by the Operational Coordination Team (OCT), the Provincial Public Health Directorate, the Provincial Disaster Management Committee and the Directorate of Economy, focusing on coordinating joint assessment efforts and response.

International Medical Corps has distributed hygiene kits to 100 eligible families in the Baghlan Markazi district, and 159 dignity kits to affected families in Baghlan Markazi and Godam Hai Talashi. The emergency response team distributed tents to 24 flood-affected families living in remote locations of (Desalah and Tala Wa Barfak) in the Doshi and Nahrin districts through joint distribution with the IOM, ANDMA and other humanitarian partners.

The emergency response team of International Medical Corps conducted a one-day training on psychological first aid for 54 community health workers (31 females, and 23 males) in gender-specific groups.
---
Burka district is one of the most remote locations in Baghlan province, where humanitarian assistance is hard to provide to affected families. International Medical Corps will be deploying two female medical doctors to the district to provide medical support in response to the increased number of sicknesses in the flood-affected areas of the district.

The International Medical Corps will continue to share updates and work within the framework established during OCT meetings to provide comprehensive support to the affected communities. Through these concerted efforts, International Medical Corps will help alleviate the floods' immediate impacts and support the region's long-term recovery.

metadata.title: Afghanistan Floods: Humanitarian Update Situation Report #1 May 14, 2024
metadata.content:
title: Afghanistan Floods: Humanitarian Update Situation Report #1 May 14, 2024 
 content: FAST FACTS
Following the heavy rainfall on May 10–11, flooding in Baghlan province resulted in more than 300 deaths, 100 injuries and more than 2,000 houses damaged or destroyed.
OUR FOOTPRINT
International Medical Corps has been operating in Afghanistan since 1984, providing primary and secondary healthcare, training, health education, emergency response, mental health, and psychosocial support (MHPSS), nutrition services, protection services, community empowerment, and water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) services.
OUR RESPONSE
International Medical Corps has so far deployed two assessment teams. We also are preparing to offer emergency shelter, non-food items (NFIs), supplies to meet the immediate needs identified in the assessments.
SITUATION UPDATE
Following significant rainfall on May 10–11, devastating floods struck Baghlan province in Afghanistan, affecting Baghlan Markazi, Burka and Nahrin districts, and Pulikhumri city. An initial Flood Need Assessment and Response Tracking Matrix, created collaboratively by International Medical Corps, the International Organization for Migration, the Afghanistan National Disaster Management Authority (ANDMA) and other humanitarian partners, revealed that the flooding killed more than 300 people, injured more than 100, and damaged or destroyed about 2,000 houses.
As need assessment efforts continue, hundreds have been reported to be trapped in their homes beneath mud, with rescue operations ongoing. The number of casualties is expected to rise significantly as the full extent of the damage is not yet determined and most people are living unsheltered on open ground. Several health facilities have been affected and reported as non-operational. Meanwhile, increased cases of waterborne illnesses—such as diarrhea and skin infections—have been reported in areas affected by flooding.

claims.sentence: footprint international medical corps operating afghanistan since 1984, providing primary secondary healthcare, training, health education, emergency response, mental health, psychosocial support (mhpss), nutrition services, protection services, community empowerment, water, sanitation, hygiene (wash) services.

As the only viable transportation to the mentioned areas is by air, a joint assessment team was deployed by helicopter to Burka district. The Jelga district of the province has just become accessible. However, more rainfall has been predicted in the coming days. Cases of acute respiratory infection with pneumonia, as well as acute watery diarrhea with dehydration, have been reported in flood-affected areas.

What lessons were learned from the May 2.summary:
The May 2018 flooding in Afghanistan, particularly in Baghlan province, underscored critical lessons for enhancing future natural disaster preparedness and response [2][6]. A key lesson learned is the urgent need for improved disaster preparedness and robust early warning systems to mitigate the devastating impact on communities and infrastructure [2][5][6]. The lack of preparedness for severe disasters often leads to a heavy reliance on humanitarian aid, highlighting the necessity for Afghanistan to develop stronger internal capacities [3].

Future improvements should prioritize community-based disaster risk reduction (CBDRR) approaches, ensuring local ownership and integrating these strategies into broader development plans [3]. Strengthening national and sub-national disaster risk management (DRM) institutions is also essential for effective coordination and response [1]. The floods demonstrated the need for multi-sectoral interventions that extend beyond immediate relief to encompass long-term recovery and resilience-building efforts [5]. Integrating climate change adaptation into disaster management frameworks is crucial, promoting climate-adaptive measures and pre-disaster early action to address increasing risks [1][5]. Moreover, the challenges in accessing affected areas due to damaged infrastructure during the 2018 response emphasized the need for resilient infrastructure and improved logistical planning for humanitarian assistance [4].
